Article_Name: Crue du Tarn en 1930 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The Tarn flood in 1930 was a centennial flood of the Tarn, its tributaries the Agout and the Aveyron, its sub-tributaries the Thoré and the Arnette, and also the Garonne. It caused a devastating flood from March 1 to 4, 1930, in several departments of southwestern France.

Thousands of houses, dozens of bridges, and kilometers of roads and railways are damaged or destroyed; hundreds of deaths are reported. In Montauban, the capital of Tarn-et-Garonne, Arthur Poncelet, Adolphe Poult, his friend René Bousquet, and Marcel Lefranc save dozens of people from drowning. In the same department, the town of Moissac is the most affected by these devastating floods. The departments of Aude, Lot-et-Garonne (notably Agen), and Tarn are also particularly impacted. These catastrophic events led to a national day of mourning on March 9, 1930 — the first in France in the 20th century — after the then-President of the Republic, Gaston Doumergue, himself originally from southern France, visited the affected areas, accompanied by André Tardieu. The French government allocated significant financial aid to rebuild the devastated areas, supported by national and international solidarity (Yugoslavia, the Netherlands, Morocco), particularly in Moissac, the most severely affected town by these exceptional floods described as the "flood of the century." François Coty contributed to the efforts by building four model farms designed by architects to withstand future floods, offering them outright to deserving families. Pope Pius XI sent a check to the Bishop of Montauban to assist the victims. The number of deaths caused by these floods is now estimated at around 700.

Article_Name: Inondation de Vaison-la-Romaine en septembre 1992 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata The flooding of Vaison-la-Romaine in September 1992 is a submersion phenomenon caused by heavy rainfall and significant ground impermeability. This disaster occurred on Monday, September 21, and Tuesday, September 22, 1992, in Vaison-la-Romaine, in the French department of Vaucluse in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. It resulted in 37 deaths and 4 disappearances [citation needed], across four municipalities.

The floods in Vaison-la-Romaine are due to a large-scale meteorological phenomenon in the southeastern region of France, affecting several departments: on September 21, 1992, heavy rains poured over the departments of Hérault, Gard, Lozère, and Ardèche, particularly on the Cévennes mountains. The commune of Le Caylar received 448 mm of rainfall in 24 hours, which was a record for the Hérault department until September 16, 2023, when Roqueredonde received 550 mm in 24 hours. These rains followed weather conditions above the norms for the region, with average temperatures higher than normal, combined with a low-pressure area in the Bay of Biscay. The next day, the rains continued in Gard, particularly in the morning, where the regions of Sommières and Nîmes were swept by a brief and violent storm accompanied by strong wind gusts, as well as part of Ardèche. The rain front then crossed the Rhône to affect the departments of Vaucluse and Drôme. The showers on September 22 resulted from a west/east storm front blocked on the western flank of Mont Ventoux starting in the afternoon. With this stationary storm system over part of the Ouvèze watershed, the commune of Orange, in the northwest of the Vaucluse department, received 51 mm of rainfall, while Carpentras, south of the Dentelles de Montmirail, received 212 mm.

The first weather alert bulletin from Météo-France, sent to the Ministry of the Interior and then to local authorities, dates back to September 21, 1992. That same evening, the prefect of Vaucluse relayed this alert to set up security and protection services. On September 22, 1992, two additional messages from Météo-France in Marignane, late at night and early in the morning, confirmed the alert, announcing storms of rare intensity. Despite this, the rain, which was heavy over Vaison-la-Romaine in the middle of the morning, stopped around noon. The city's emergency services faced several challenges: the events occurred on a Tuesday, the day of the weekly market, with increased crowds; evacuation requests made to customers and tourists (numerous at the end of the summer season) at the municipal campsite, located upstream of the Roman bridge, had little effect. The first moderate downpour (17.8 mm) fell between 10 a.m. and noon. It was followed, in the early afternoon, by a much more violent one (182.7 mm) that lasted until 3:15 p.m. The teachers at Jules Ferry School, then located near the Ouvèze river, secured the students on the first floor of the building farthest from the river. The total rainfall in Entrechaux was 300 mm (300 liters of water per square meter) in six hours (possibly slightly more locally). For comparison, the annual average rainfall in Paris is 637 mm. During this meteorological event, nearly 1,320 km² received more than 100 mm of rainfall. The storm, of unprecedented violence, stagnated over the slopes of Mont Ventoux for several hours. It poured 215 mm of water in Malaucène, 179 mm in Vaison, and 143 mm in Buis-les-Baronnies. The heavy rains upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine were such that a mudslide, about 50 cm thick, invaded and completely covered the municipal campsite around 3 p.m. A water height of 10 cm already covered the streets of the lower town. The first news arrived: there were deaths at the Moulin de César campsite. The section reserved for the À cœur joie associative campsite—450 pitches—was swept away. It was reported that there were numerous victims in the Théos neighborhood subdivision, located on the right bank, which was submerged by the floodwaters. At the same time, a torrent of mud swept through the municipal campsite, carrying everything in its path: caravans, vehicles, and campers. In the minutes that followed, at the level of the Roman bridge, whose deck is less than twenty meters above the river's normal level, the water reached 17 meters, 15 meters above its normal course. Images of caravans crashing against the Roman bridge remain etched in memories. The fire station, located near the Ouvèze riverbed, was flooded, including the building and rescue equipment. The ORSEC plan was activated at 5 p.m. The water level began to recede only after 10 p.m. Of the three bridges over the Ouvèze, only the ancient Roman bridge withstood the flood, despite some damage to its parapet.

Later, it will be learned that the same phenomenon had already occurred, at least once, in Vaison. In the municipal archives of the city, a deliberation dated August 1616 indicates that "the city council had to repair the parapet of the Roman bridge destroyed by a flood that also swept away several houses." No victims were reported. In the 17th century, the inhabitants of Vaison lived in the upper town, and around the cathedral, covering the ruins of ancient Vasio, there were only gardens. The risk was, however, known but neglected. Before the tragedy, following the disaster of October 3, 1988, in Nîmes, engineer Ponton mentioned in his April 1989 report 62 towns, including Vaison-la-Romaine, likely to be affected by floods caused by rainwater runoff. Jean-Pierre Mazeillier had described Vaison's Land Use Plan (POS) as "completely insane" when he took over the technical services of the town hall and could not find any trace of Ponton's report. The 1982 Deferre decentralization law had transferred urban planning authority from the prefect to the mayors. On October 14, 1983, the then-mayor, André Thès, revised the POS and declared the right bank of the Ouvèze constructible over more than a kilometer. The area had not even been classified as a "minor flood zone." The price of the land had increased by a factor of more than 10. Scientific studies were conducted on the 1992 centennial flood. They provide the reasons for the extent of the damage. In the area of the Salette torrent, a tributary of the Brégoux, itself a tributary of the Ouvèze, in the heart of the Dentelles de Montmirail, 200.5 millimeters of rain fell within five hours. The figures are known thanks to the Bernardins station in Beaumes-de-Venise. This represented a volume of 4.2 million cubic meters of water falling into the watershed of this torrent, which has an area of only 28 km². The report of the commission of inquiry on "the causes of floods and ways to remedy them" also mentions other reasons such as a specific geological impermeability in this Ouvèze valley but also aggravating anthropogenic modifications: "an impermeabilization of the soil causing urban rainwater runoff and finally the presence of constructions in the very bed of the river." The Ouvèze is a 123 km river, originating in Montauban-sur-Ouvèze, in the Drôme department, and flowing into the Rhône at Sorgues, after passing through 28 municipalities. Many watercourses are tributaries of the Ouvèze, notably the Toulourenc, between Mollans-sur-Ouvèze and Entrechaux. Of the 820 km² of the Ouvèze watershed, 580 km² are located upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine.

This tragedy of September 22 caused the death of more than 40 people, swept away by the Ouvèze or its tributaries. The most commonly cited number of victims is 46 dead, plus one in Beaumes-de-Venise, regularly omitted from statistics. Thirty-eight people lost their lives that day in Haut-Vaucluse, including 34 in Vaison-la-Romaine. Among them were fifteen residents of the Theos housing estate and at least eleven residents of the Moulin de César campsite. This extraordinary flood struck many villages downstream of Vaison, also causing deaths: three in Séguret; an elderly farmer who went to fetch his cow in Gigondas, which was found alive; four campers swept away by the Brégoux waters in Aubignan; a pedestrian who tried to cross the bridge swept away by the Salette flood in Beaumes-de-Venise, as well as four missing persons, including a six-month-old baby. Nine months later, in 1993, a body was found in the commune of Roaix by a firefighter with a search dog from Vaison. Without the courage of a firefighter who saved 36 people with a borrowed boat, the death toll would have been much higher. As the waters receded on the morning of September 23, bulldozers and trucks were able to work in the streets to remove vehicle carcasses covered in river silt and all the debris it had carried. To prevent looting, the flooded area was cordoned off by the army, with soldiers monitoring the entrances to the city and the main affected villages and patrolling in front of houses. In the five years following the disaster, the investigation stalled. Only the prefect of Vaucluse, who was in office in 1965, was implicated in 1995. The judge closed the investigation at the beginning of 1998 after ordering new inquiries into the studies conducted for building permits. These "clearly implicated the systematic concreting of risk areas, particularly the natural flood expansion basins of rivers and streams." Two years after the disaster, building permit applications were submitted to construct in the city's flood-prone areas. Some survivors in Vaison were able to resettle in Clos d'Ariston, a plot purchased and developed by the municipality. Few of them left the city, as insurance compensated them well, and others were able to purchase older properties.

The material damage was estimated at 500 million francs (a little over 76 million euros). Despite spontaneous solidarity, subsidies, and insurance reimbursements, the municipality became heavily indebted. More than 19,000 F per inhabitant (approximately 2,890 €). In the five years following the disaster, 115 million francs of work were carried out, equivalent to 17.5 million euros. Furthermore, this renovation had an increased cost. The final bill amounted to nearly 460 million euros in damages, including 20 million for Vaison alone. Ultimately, for this single municipality, the work amounted to approximately 26 million euros, of which nearly 8 million was borne by Vaison and its 6,000 inhabitants. While everything was done to prevent another disaster, it came at the cost of heavy indebtedness.

It is true that Vaison, being a tourist town, needed to quickly restore an image consistent with its objectives. The first measure taken was to make the areas along the Ouvèze non-buildable. Seventy homes, including an entire housing development, were demolished. The riverbed was widened, and the banks were reinforced. Upstream, the municipal campsite was relocated and elevated. Where the Théos housing development once stood, massive stone blocks reinforced the bank, and a natural area was created. Further along, a fitness trail now covers the former Jardins de l'Ouvèze neighborhood, and the Eminées and Magnans housing developments have been turned into green spaces. The school was rebuilt. It is protected, like the lower town, by a long wall serving as a dike. Evacuation drills are held every year in all classes. If intervention were needed, the Vaison firefighters, thanks to alert systems, are notified of a flood in T + 2. Two hours, which cannot be shortened but are sufficient to evacuate everyone. The alert is given thanks to the installation of weather radars in Bollène and the Gard. In 1992, according to the mayor at the time, there were none, although there was one in Nîmes named Mélody, but it had been struck by lightning the evening before...

On the left bank of the Ouvèze, the industrial area has healed its wounds, but it has not relocated. Many have reopened their businesses on-site for economic reasons: relocating would have required both purchasing new land and rebuilding, and insurance did not cover it. However, a new business area was created at a higher elevation but attracted only two companies. Moreover, "local media regularly report on local urban planning (PLU) being challenged and most often annulled a few months later by the courts. The main reasons are almost always, in addition to procedural irregularities, the transformation of agricultural land, often located in flood-prone areas or adjacent to them, into building plots." The primary cause is that land prices have skyrocketed throughout the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. Due to quality of life and sunshine, it is the region in France with the fastest-growing population, attracting retirees as well as active families. Thus, for some, the temptation is great to multiply the value of agricultural land by twenty or thirty times simply by reclassifying it as building land. In the event of a flood, even less severe than that of September 22, everyone knows that the damage would be considerable, including loss of human life.

Whole_Text.header: The floods in Vaucluse, Ardèche, and Drôme
Whole_Text.content: Sixty-three municipalities were affected in Vaucluse, the most impacted, besides Vaison, being Séguret, Gigondas, Beaumes-de-Venise, and Aubignan, as well as Violès, Bédarrides, Jonquières, and Sarrians. The following day, the extent of the damage was discovered: roads swept away, vineyards destroyed, bridges demolished such as those in Roaix and Beaumes-de-Venise. A desolation that worsened in the municipalities of Vaucluse affected by the flood, with 2,300 houses or businesses damaged in the department, including 320 in Vaison that were either destroyed or required repairs. However, Vaucluse was not the only affected department. On September 22, there was a centennial flood of the Ardèche, which caused five deaths in the southern part of the department, between Pont-de-Labeaume and Aubenas. The Drôme department was also severely impacted, with water rising over 2 meters in some villages along the Ouvèze. The municipality of Sainte-Jalle was particularly affected.

Article_Name: Inondation du 3 octobre 1988 de Nîmes — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The Nîmes flood of October 3, 1988, resulted from a Mediterranean episode that caused heavy rainfall in Nîmes, in the Gard region. This natural disaster caused around ten deaths and affected 70 municipalities around Nîmes. This flood left a lasting impression on local memory and is regularly commemorated. It is estimated that the return period of the event is approximately centennial (a one in a hundred chance of occurring each year).

During the night of October 2 to 3, 1988, and the morning of October 3, storm bands crossed southeastern France during a Mediterranean episode. Radar echoes from the night show that the storm originated southwest of the Gulf of Aigues-Mortes (south of Montpellier). The storm system initially moved up the lower Vidourle valley, causing significant rainfall in the Sommières area late in the evening of October 2. The phenomenon then gained in size and intensity, heading toward the Nîmes heights, first passing through the Vaunage plain, where 250 to nearly 400 mm of rain were recorded on average over the entire episode, particularly in Calvisson. Significant hailstorms were reported in the commune of Congénies around 4 a.m. The rainfall reached 50 mm or more per hour on average over a period of less than 12 hours, equating to six months of rain. The torrential storm then spread and stalled over the entire garrigue plateaus overlooking Nîmes toward Remoulins. At the Nîmes-Courbessac meteorological station, east of the city, 263 mm fell during the night of October 2 to 3. At Nîmes-Kennedy, 311 mm were recorded by 1 p.m. The most intense rainfall core recorded was 420 mm at Mas-de-Ponge, on the heights northwest of the city. This considerable value is, however, underestimated because the rain gauge stopped transmitting data for about forty minutes during the episode. Locally, 500 mm may have been recorded, equivalent to two-thirds of the annual rainfall. The karst networks quickly became saturated, charging all the cadereaux toward the city center. However, the rainfall was relatively localized, as at Nîmes-Garons airport, only 6 km southeast of the city, only 35 mm were recorded. The very tight isohyet curves during the event are typical of stationary storm phenomena. The Nîmes urban area, located at the confluence of cadereaux, at the foot of the limestone plateaus of the garrigues, is particularly prone to flood risks from runoff. The first indications of flooding in Nîmes date back to the 14th century. Historical chronicles notably mention two major disasters equivalent to that of October 3, 1988: August 29, 1399, and September 9, 1557.

There were then counted ten[2] or eleven deaths, including two helicopter pilots who were providing assistance, and 45,000 victims. A total of 70 municipalities around Nîmes were subsequently classified as a natural disaster zone[4]. The damages were estimated at over 600 million euros[4],[9].
Some of the residents quickly spread a conspiracy theory accusing the authorities of hiding the real number of deaths to avoid panicking the population.

Article_Name: Inondation de 2022 à Yagoua — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The flood in Yagoua in 2022 in Cameroon is a natural disaster that began in June 2022 and continued until the end of August 2022 in the Far North region. The influx of water was recorded in about twenty localities located in two departments of the region, Mayo-Danay and Logone-et-Chari.

The heavy rains caused the Logone River and the artificial Maga Lake to overflow their banks. This is the largest overflow since 2012. The affected area, Yagoua, a commune in Cameroon located in the Far North region, the capital of the Mayo-Danay department, specifically in the neighborhoods of Goboïssou, Kaskao, Danayré, the municipal grounds, and two primary and nursery schools.
The flood affected 43,000 victims.

Whole_Text.header: Management of the crisis by the authorities
Whole_Text.content: Three months after the end of the avalanches, the populations began, in December 2022, to return to their localities and villages of origin. The temporary resettlement sites in the city of Kousseri (Logone and Chari) are in the process of being cleared. In January 2023, the displaced people started making bricks and some construction materials to repair their homes.

Article_Name: Inondation de 2012 à Yagoua — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The 2012 flood in Yagoua, Cameroon, is a natural disaster that began on August 10, 2012, in the Far North region. The influx of water was recorded in about twenty localities located in two municipalities of the Mayo-Danay department, Yagoua and Maga.

The commune of Yagoua is a commune in Cameroon located in the Far North region, covering an area of 950 km². It is bordered to the west by the commune of Guere, to the south by the commune of Wina, to the southeast by the communes of Guere and Gobo, to the east by the Logone River, a natural border between Cameroon and the Republic of Chad, to the north by the commune of Vele, and to the northwest by the commune of Kalfou.

The torrential rains of 2012 caused very significant flooding in the villages, fields, and pastures of the northern Cameroon region. Flooding was worsened by the forced opening of the Lagdo dam gates near Garoua, which was at risk of collapsing under pressure.

Rice producers estimate an average equivalent of 200 bags of rice each. The sale of the bags least affected by water is done at half price.  
The Yagoua Rice Expansion and Modernization Company, abbreviated as SEMRY, estimates losses at 25,000 tons for Maga and 20,000 tons for Yagoua.

Whole_Text.header: Management of the crisis by the authorities
Whole_Text.content: In 2013, through a loan agreement with the World Bank, the Cameroonian government, via the Ministry of Economy, Planning, and Regional Development, launched the Emergency Flood Control Project, abbreviated as PULCI[4].

Article_Name: Inondation de 2012 à Maga — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The flooding in Maga in 2012 in Cameroon is a natural disaster that began on August 10, 2012, in the Far North region. The influx of water was recorded in about twenty localities located in two municipalities of the Mayo-Danay department, Yagoua and Maga.
The flooding occurred in Maga, a commune in Cameroon located in the Mayo-Danay department, near the border with Chad.
The torrential rains allowed for an accumulation of water observed on August 10, 2012[1].

Doctors Without Borders reports 2,100 affected individuals being monitored since mid-October [2]. The recorded toll indicates more than 30 deaths and several hundred thousand affected individuals up to neighboring Nigeria [1].

Rice producers estimate an average equivalent of 200 bags of rice each. The sale of bags least affected by water is done at half price. The Maga Rice Expansion and Modernization Company, abbreviated SEMRY, estimates losses at 25,000 tons for Maga. The mayor of the Maga municipality fears a possibility of famine in this locality.

Whole_Text.header: Management of the crisis by the authorities
Whole_Text.content: On September 20, 2012, the President of the Republic, Paul Biya, visited the populations affected by the floods in the Northern and Far North Regions. In 2013, through a loan agreement with the World Bank, the Cameroonian government, via the Ministry of Economy, Planning, and Regional Development, launched the Emergency Flood Control Project, abbreviated as PULCI. The project involves the refurbishment of the Maga dam, nearly 70 km of the Logone River dike, as well as related water supply and irrigation infrastructure.

Article_Name: Inondation de 1856 en France — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1856 in France affected a large number of rivers and remains a reference flood. It impacted, at the end of May-beginning of June, the Rhône or the Loire, devastating Lyon, Avignon, Tarascon which was cut off from Avignon, etc.

The flood of the Loire in 1856 remains to this day the most significant since 1790. It covered nearly 100,000 hectares, destroyed nearly 23 km of dikes, and caused the death of about thirty people in the Maine-et-Loire department alone. However, upstream of the confluence with the Allier, the level of this 1856 flood was significantly lower than in 1846 and 1866, and equivalent to that of 1907. Many towns were partially submerged: Blois, Tours, Trélazé, etc. In the latter municipality, the Ardoisières quarry was engulfed, causing production to halt for several months. Many old houses bear flood marks of the Loire on their walls. Many of these date back to the campaign of commemorative plaque installation in the flooded areas, which was undertaken in 1856 to preserve the memory of the disaster.

On June 1, 1856, the waters began to recede in Arles, but the damage was immense: In Avignon, on June 3, 1856, the flood swept away part of the ramparts between the St-Roch gate and the St-Dominique gate. In Lyon, the damage was very significant, particularly on the left bank, which was undergoing a period of construction. 18 people died in the commune of La Guillotière. Photographer Édouard Baldus, at the request of the Administration of Fine Arts, created a report (probably one of the very first photographic reports after those of the Crimean War) on the devastating Rhône floods in Lyon, Avignon, and Tarascon. We also have photographs taken by Louis Froissard, photographer for the municipal road service of Lyon.

Napoleon III will visit the damage in the south of France starting the first week of June 1856. He goes to Lyon (June 2, 1856), Dijon, Valence, Arles, and navigates through the streets of Tarascon. After a stop in Paris on June 5, 1856, he travels to Orléans, Blois, Angers, and Tours, also affected by the flooding of the Loire. This visit was not without political motives: he does not forget to pass through the commune of Trélazé, where the Marianne riots had taken place a year earlier. A decree dated June 2, 1856, allocates 300,000 francs to Lyon. Isère, Drôme, etc., also receive funds, while 27 million francs are allocated to repair bridges, churches, fountains, etc. Empress Eugénie launches a subscription, in which the Faubourg Saint-Antoine notably participates.

Article_Name: Canicule de 2007 aux États-Unis — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The 2007 heatwave in the United States is an extreme climatic event that affected several regions of the United States between June and August of 2007. Characterized by two distinct heatwaves, it first impacted the western coast of the country before spreading to the Midwest plains later. Temperatures ranging from 40°C (Memphis) to 47°C (Las Vegas) were recorded, causing the deaths of several dozen people across the country.

The 2007 heatwave affected the United States starting at the end of June. An initial heatwave hit the western regions of the country from June 25, with temperatures nearing or exceeding 40°C locally in Montana, Washington State, Arizona, Nevada, and California. In the following days, the phenomenon intensified, and record values were recorded in southern Nevada and western Arizona. On July 5, 43°C was recorded in Reno, breaking the previous record from 1970, while 47°C was recorded in Las Vegas. A peak temperature was recorded in Baker, California, where the mercury rose to 51°C. In Las Vegas, as in several other cities in the region, the intensive use of air conditioners caused a series of power surges on the electrical grid, leaving entire neighborhoods without power. In Reno, the Salvation Army opened an emergency shelter for people without air conditioners. A one-year-old child found dead in a car in Orofino, Idaho, was one of the first victims of the heatwave to be reported. The drought and extreme temperatures caused several fires to break out. In Utah, 1,150 km² of vegetation were destroyed by flames, forcing authorities to evacuate some homes and close access to highways I-15 and I-70. Three people died as a result of the disaster. After a period of relative respite, a new heatwave hit the country starting on July 9, this time reaching the Midwest plains, the South, and part of the East Coast. States like Tennessee and Missouri were particularly affected by the phenomenon, with temperatures nearing 40°C recorded in several localities. On July 11, 37.7°C was recorded in some localities in New Jersey. To limit accidents, the New York City municipality decided to open nearly 300 air-conditioned emergency centers. On August 16, Tennessee authorities announced a toll of nine deaths, while the Missouri Department of Health reported seven victims. In Illinois, eight people died as a result of this heatwave.

Article_Name: Canicule européenne de juillet 1983 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about meteorology or climatology. edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The July 1983 heatwave is a heatwave during which high temperatures affected Italy and the Southeast of France in the last weeks of July 1983. In France, it took place from July 9 to 31 and particularly impacted Marseille, which recorded an excess mortality of 300 deaths in its region alone[1],[2]. It is considered in Italy as one of the most significant heatwaves the country has experienced since World War II[3].

From July 10 to July 23, an anticyclonic blockage persists most of the time, which allows stable, hot, and very dry weather to be maintained over southern and western Europe. This anticyclone transports very hot air over a large part of Europe despite some occasional weaknesses, but this anticyclonic blockage is not the only cause of this heatwave; it is also due to the fact that a depression has settled over the Bay of Biscay.
The El Niño phenomenon of 1982-1983 lasted 16 months. It is one of the six largest El Niño events since 1856[4].

Several temperature records were reached in Italy. The meteorological station of the Ximenes Observatory recorded a temperature of 41.6°C for the Italian city of Florence on July 26, 1983, a record considered historic for the city, surpassing the temperature of 40.2°C recorded on August 1, 1958. Peaks above 40 degrees were observed in several Italian localities, including the cities of Cagliari (43.7°C), Reggio Calabria (44.2°C), Ancona (40.5°C), and Arezzo (40.3°C). On July 31, temperatures of 42.5°C were observed in Saint-Raphaël, 42°C in Paray-le-Monial (Saône-et-Loire), 41°C in Vichy, Clermont-Ferrand, and Saint-Étienne, 39°C in Besançon, Mâcon, Mulhouse, and Saint-Dizier, 38°C in Bourg-Saint-Maurice (850 m altitude), and 37°C in Chamonix (1000 m altitude).

The year 1983, with 92,000 deaths during the July-August period, is one of the years, along with 2003 and its 99,000 deaths, with the highest mortality rate during the July-August period. The excess mortality during June and July 1983, across France as a whole, amounted to a total of 4,700 deaths. The city of Marseille, which experienced maximum temperatures between 35 and 40 degrees, recorded an excess mortality of around 300 deaths during the heatwave, directly or indirectly attributable to it.
Several prevention procedures were implemented following this heatwave[7].

Article_Name: Vague de chaleur de l'été 1947 en Europe — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: Heatwave of the summer of 1947 in Europe
Whole_Text.content: The heatwave of the summer of 1947 in Europe is an exceptionally significant climatic event that occurred from June to August 1947. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since the beginning of records. Numerous temperature records were recorded.

The summer of 1947 is part of a series of scorching summers that affected Western Europe in the years following World War II (1945, 1947, 1949, 1950, and 1952). During 1947, temperatures were consistently above average from April to early October. Europe experienced three notable heatwaves (21 days): from June 26 to 28 (low intensity), from July 22 to August 4 (exceptional intensity), and from August 14 to 20 (moderate intensity). The spring had been abnormally warm, with unusual temperatures starting in April, as 30°C was reached in many regions of France during the second half of the month, and even exceeded in the south. On May 27, Saharan air swept over France, with temperatures exceeding 30°C in the northern half and approaching 35°C in the southern part. After a respite in mid-June, a first heatwave hit Europe during the last decade of June. In France, between June 26 and 28, temperatures exceeded 35°C across much of the country. After a break in mid-July, a new heatwave—comparable to the August 2003 heatwave—occurred from July 22 to August 4. According to Météo-France, it was "the most intense heatwave episode since the post-war period, after the August 2003 heatwave," and even since 1873, the year when Météo-France's chronological data began. In some places, such as the Paris region, absolute records were observed: on July 28, 1947, temperatures reached 40.4°C. This record would only be broken 72 years later, on July 25, 2019, with 42.6°C. 

In southern France, the peak of the heatwave was reached on August 2 and 3, with 40°C in Lyon and even higher temperatures further south. On August 3 and 4, storms brought an end to this heatwave. However, a new, more moderate heatwave occurred between August 14 and 20, with temperatures again exceeding 35°C across France, except along the coasts. A final heatwave took place during the second decade of September, with maximum temperatures still exceeding 30°C at most weather stations. In 1947, the heat was certainly less concentrated than in 2003, and the humanitarian consequences were less critical for a population less exposed. However, the episodes of extreme heat in 1947 were never as widespread since the beginning of records. The Alpine glacier systems recorded historic losses, which they would not recover from thereafter.

Article_Name: Canicule de 2013 aux États-Unis — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The 2013 heatwave in the United States is an extreme weather event that affected most of the Southwestern United States, specifically California, Nevada, and Arizona, from late June to early July 2013.

The mercury reached 38°C in Utah and 54°C in the Death Valley desert, which is the highest temperature ever recorded on Earth for the month of June, only three degrees lower than the highest temperature ever recorded in Death Valley, 57°C, recorded in July 1913. The mercury still reached 48°C in Phoenix and 47°C in Las Vegas. During the night, the mercury fluctuated between 20 and 35°C, posing a real danger to the human body, which cannot cool down at any time. However, the relative humidity was exceptionally low, often below 10%, making the extreme heat more "bearable." During this heatwave, forecasters recorded 46°C in Phoenix, 42°C in Tucson, and 43°C in Las Vegas on a Saturday just by midday, but it was expected that the mercury would rise further in the afternoon. At noon, the thermometer read 45°C in Death Valley, at Furnace Creek. Death Valley is one of the hottest places on the globe.

This extreme heatwave, combined with a very severe drought that is not unusual at this time of year in the southwestern United States, was caused by an Omega block in the atmospheric circulation at high altitude. Thus, there were two depressions located on either side of an anticyclone. On their western equatorial periphery, the high pressures carried very hot and humid air from Mexico in a south to southwest sector flow, which dried out and warmed further due to the foehn effect as it passed over the Rocky Mountains. Thus, in the plains, there was a completely clear sky, sunny weather, and extremely high temperatures, most exceeding 40°C and approaching 50°C.

It was particularly hot in the western United States, even though most of the states there are accustomed to scorching summers. Authorities spoke of a deadly heatwave. Numerous cases of hospitalizations were reported, including 34 in Las Vegas at an outdoor concert due to sunburns and heatstroke, while 170 others suffered from nausea and exhaustion. The extreme heat made roads and sidewalks extremely hot. Authorities feared that migrants attempting to cross the border clandestinely between Mexico and the United States might die in the desert; consequently, reinforcements were deployed to monitor the border on the American side. Seven people were found dead in the Sonoran Desert in Arizona. An elderly person was discovered dead in their home in Las Vegas, as they did not have air conditioning. In Oregon, about forty sheep succumbed to the heat, while more than 200 other animals had to be rescued. The paws of dogs and cats had to be protected from burns caused by the scorching asphalt. Additionally, and particularly in California, the extreme heat hindered airplane takeoffs, leaving them grounded. Numerous fires were reported, including a massive one in California that caused the death of 19 firefighters who were trying to combat the blaze. This extreme heatwave was one of the most intense ever observed in the world: temperatures close to some of the world's heat records were recorded in certain states.

Article_Name: Canicule européenne d'août 2020 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a draft concerning meteorology or climatology and Europe. Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The European heatwave of August 2020 is a climatic event of exceptional magnitude that occurred in August 2020. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since records began. Numerous temperature records were recorded. It occurred one year after the heatwaves of June and July 2019.

If this heatwave was of moderate intensity for the south of France, it was unprecedented in the north of the country where a red alert was issued by Météo France. At the peak of the episode, more than three-quarters of France were under a heatwave alert. Fifty-four French departments were placed at the orange level, from Midi-Pyrénées to the northeast. More impressively, the 15 departments of Haute-Normandie, Hauts-de-France, and Île-de-France were placed on RED alert from Friday, August 7, to Tuesday, August 11. This heatwave is an exceptionally significant climatic event that occurred in August 2020. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since records began. Numerous temperature records were recorded. An initial heat peak occurred on July 30 and 31, with the heat arriving from the southwest and then moving towards the western and eastern regions. On July 30, temperatures of 41.9°C were recorded in Socoa (a new absolute heat record), 40.6°C in Cazaux (monthly record), and 38.3°C in Royan (monthly record). The next day, temperatures of 41.3°C were recorded in Vichy, 39.4°C in Nevers, and 37.9°C in Boulogne-sur-Mer. The heat then shifted towards the southeast, and temperatures eventually returned to more bearable levels. However, this respite was only temporary as a new, longer heatwave arrived on August 6. Numerous monthly and even absolute heat records were recorded on August 7 in western France, with 41.9°C in Bellis in the Landes (absolute record), 39.8°C in Cognac, 39.6°C in Nantes, and 33.4°C in Cherbourg (monthly records). Temperatures then dropped in the west, but the heat intensified in the north and east of the country. August 8 and 9 were the hottest days in northern and eastern France. On August 8, the mercury reached 37.1°C in Lille (monthly record). Also noteworthy on the same day were minimum temperatures of 25.2°C in Boulogne-sur-Mer and 22.2°C in Alençon (absolute records). The next day, temperatures reached 39.3°C in Creil and 38.4°C in Rouen (monthly records). The temperature did not drop below 23°C in Lille (monthly record) or 21.4°C in Beauvais (absolute record). On August 10, the heatwave lost some intensity but remained quite strong. It was not until August 13 that the heatwave subsided, with the arrival of numerous storms. On a national scale, this episode was shorter and less intense than that of 2003, but in some departments, it was of an intensity close to or even locally exceeding that of 2003 (for example, in Lille, where the average temperature over seven days exceeded by 1°C the highest average temperature recorded over seven days in 2003). The first half of this August was the second hottest ever recorded (though far behind 2003), and this August was the third hottest ever recorded, with a 2°C excess compared to the 1981–2010 average, behind 2003 (+4.2°C) and 1997 (+2.1°C). It would later be surpassed by August 2022. The heatwave is estimated to have caused 1,900 deaths.

It lasted 12 days (from August 5 to 16, 2020), which remains a fairly high value for a heatwave, but it is especially its intensity that is remarkable. With 8 days above 30°C, it is the 4th highest value observed, behind the heatwaves of 1976 (17 days), 1911 (14 days), and 2018 (9 days). These 8 days were consecutive (from August 6 to 13 inclusive), however, only one longer series has been observed: in 1976, temperatures exceeded 30°C from June 24 to July 8, i.e., for 15 consecutive days. But this high intensity led to the RED heatwave alert being triggered in Belgium for the first time in history. The record in Uccle was 35.9°C. However, this record had been surpassed on July 31, with 36.5°C, making it the third hottest day ever recorded in Uccle. The main victims of the heatwave's effects: 742 people aged over 85 and 600 others in the 65 to 84 age group.

Temperatures in the United Kingdom reached 34°C or higher for six consecutive days. Five tropical nights (temperature not dropping below 20°C) were recorded in the United Kingdom in August, including four consecutive ones. Additionally, at least 20 stations across the United Kingdom recorded temperatures of 32°C or higher for six consecutive days for the first time since the great heatwave of 1976.

The Netherlands experienced a national heatwave from August 5 to 16, lasting a total of 13 days. For 9 days, temperatures exceeded 30 degrees. For the very first time, the Netherlands had eight consecutive days with temperatures above 30. This heatwave caused approximately 400 deaths.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴西馬侖 (2001年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Cimaron (English: Severe Tropical Storm Cimaron, International Number: 0101, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 03W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Crising) was the first named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Cimaron" was provided by the Philippines and refers to a type of wild buffalo in the region.

At 12:00 UTC on May 9, a tropical depression formed over the sea between Mindoro Island and Palawan Island in the Philippines. The tropical depression moved northward. At 00:00 UTC on May 11, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm west of Luzon Island and was named Cimaron. Cimaron turned to move in a northeast direction. At 00:00 UTC on May 13, Cimaron further intensified into a severe tropical storm south of Taiwan. At 06:00 UTC on May 13, Cimaron weakened into a tropical storm. Cimaron maintained its northeastward path until 09:00 UTC on May 14 in southern Japan. Cimaron then moved eastward and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the sea northeast of Okinawa at 12:00 UTC on May 14. It completely dissipated at 18:00 UTC on May 15. [1]

At 11:15 am on May 11, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning. At 8:35 pm, the Central Weather Bureau issued a land typhoon warning. At 5:50 pm on May 13, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the land typhoon warning. At 8:05 pm, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning.

Article_Name: 庚子風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Gengzi Typhoon Disaster occurred on November 10, 1900, when a powerful typhoon directly struck Hong Kong, resulting in over 200 fatalities. It was the fifth deadliest typhoon in Hong Kong's history, the only typhoon to directly hit Hong Kong in November, and the latest in the year to do so. It was also one of the strongest typhoons to hit Hong Kong before World War II.

The Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the red downward cone at 11:45 am on November 8, indicating that a tropical cyclone was gathering more than 300 miles (480 kilometers) south of Hong Kong, with fresh to strong north to northeast winds expected in Hong Kong. At 11:50 am on November 9, the Observatory hoisted the black downward cone, signaling strong east to northeast winds with the possibility of reaching gale force. That afternoon, the typhoon showed signs of directly impacting Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to sound the typhoon gun at 6:15 pm, forecasting that wind strength in Hong Kong would increase to gale force. By 7:30 pm, the Observatory vertically hoisted two lanterns. Between 5:00 am and 6:00 am on November 10, the Observatory recorded a maximum average wind speed of 61 knots, equivalent to 113 kilometers per hour, reaching storm force. The typhoon passed over the eastern part of Hong Kong around 6:00 to 7:00 am. Subsequently, the wind in Hong Kong weakened to gale force and shifted to westerly winds, leading the Observatory to replace the black drum at 6:40 am. Later, as the typhoon moved north of Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the black upward cone at 8:45 am. In the afternoon, the wind in Hong Kong further subsided, and the Observatory finally removed all typhoon signals at 4:00 pm.

Article_Name: 己卯風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Ji-Mao Typhoon disaster was caused by Typhoon 23W during the 1939 Pacific typhoon season. The typhoon passed through British Hong Kong on November 23, 1939, prompting the Royal Hong Kong Observatory to hoist the No. 9 typhoon signal twice.

On November 18, 1939, a tropical depression was detected east of Mindanao, which continued to strengthen and move northwest, intensifying into a typhoon before sweeping across Samar and Leyte on the 19th. The typhoon then generally moved westward until reaching the western South China Sea on the 22nd. Subsequently, a cold front caused the typhoon to turn northeast, resulting in the rare phenomenon of a typhoon reversing direction to the northeast in the western South China Sea. On November 24, the typhoon passed through Macau and, two hours later, its eye directly crossed Hong Kong. The eye lingered over the Hong Kong Observatory for fifteen minutes, marking the first recorded instance of this occurrence at the observatory. After causing landslides, the typhoon began transitioning into an extratropical cyclone and continued moving northeast across southern China. The storm gradually weakened as it crossed the Taiwan Strait and dissipated on the 26th after making landfall in Taiwan.

While crossing the Philippines, a weather station in Capiz on Panay Island recorded a pressure as low as 981.0 hPa, and wind speeds exceeding 88 km/h. During its passage, the storm caused a motorboat to sink off Masbate Island, resulting in the deaths of 48 out of 50 people on board. In Balangiga, Eastern Samar, one person went missing, believed to have drowned and presumed dead. Significant property damage was also reported in Samar, Leyte, and Capiz provinces.

Typhoon 23W entered within 800 kilometers south of Hong Kong and moved northwest-northward, approaching the eastern waters of Hainan Island. It came within 400 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong but did not further move northward to make landfall in western Guangdong. Two days later, it made an unexpected 90-degree sharp turn, creating a rare situation of moving directly from west to east towards Hong Kong, passing about 65 kilometers southeast-south of the Hong Kong Observatory. The Observatory issued the No. 9 signal twice. The cold air from the northeast monsoon also happened to move southward, and the storm transformed into an extratropical cyclone the next day, moving eastward towards Taiwan. The Observatory headquarters recorded strong winds for one hour, with the highest hourly average wind speed at 65 kilometers per hour, coming from the east.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 8:35 a.m. on November 23, then upgraded to the No. 8 signal at 9:05 a.m. As the storm continued to approach and the wind and rain intensified, the No. 9 signal was issued at 10:05 a.m. At 11:45 a.m., as the wind and rain slightly eased, the Observatory downgraded to the No. 8 signal. However, as the wind and rain intensified again, the No. 9 signal was reissued at 3:51 p.m. At 4:30 p.m., the Observatory downgraded to the No. 5 signal. By 7:05 p.m., all signals were canceled.

When Hong Kong was affected by the rainbands ahead of the storm, gusts reached up to 119 km/h. Rainfall began seven hours before the typhoon's arrival, resulting in a total of approximately 108 mm of rainfall. The heaviest rainfall came from the pre-typhoon rainbands, with 40 mm recorded within one hour. The lowest pressure recorded during the typhoon's passage over Hong Kong was 989.0 hPa. The typhoon caused minor damage in Hong Kong. In Kowloon City’s Tung Tau Village, a mud wall collapsed, killing two people. In Kowloon Bay, a cargo boat was overturned by the wind, causing five people to fall into the sea, with one person sustaining minor injuries.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gilda (English: Typhoon Gilda, International Number: 6733, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 39W) was the 33rd named tropical cyclone of the 1967 Pacific typhoon season.

On November 8, Typhoon Gilda formed over the eastern waters of the Caroline Islands. On November 18, 1967, Typhoon Gilda made landfall in Taiwan between Hualien and Chenggong. After exiting between Taichung and Hsinchu, it weakened into a tropical depression in the northern Taiwan Strait. The intense Typhoon Gilda became the "latest typhoon to hit Taiwan in a year" in Taiwan's meteorological observation history at the time. On December 3, 2004, Typhoon Nanmadol replaced Typhoon Gilda as the "latest typhoon to hit Taiwan in a year" in Taiwan's meteorological observation history.

Article_Name: 丁卯風災 (1927年8月) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Dingmao Typhoon occurred on August 20, 1927. On that day, a typhoon passed through the coastal waters near Yangjiang, Guangdong Province, China. The storm caused loss of life and property damage in both Hong Kong and Macau, and it was one of the two occasions that year when Macau hoisted the No. 7 typhoon signal (equivalent to today's No. 10 signal). A newspaper article once mentioned, "Um violento tufão caiu sobre Macau (A violent typhoon struck Macau)." The Central Meteorological Bureau's designation for this typhoon was B124.

According to the path map of the typhoon on August 20, 1927, released by the Macau Meteorological Bureau, the storm formed over the sea south of Guam at 6 a.m. on August 15, moving steadily westward. On August 16, the storm moved west of 140°E longitude and gradually shifted from a west-northwest to northwest direction, intensifying rapidly. On August 18, the Dutch steamship Sapoeroea recorded the typhoon's lowest sea-level pressure at only 886.7 hPa (26.185 inches of mercury) 460 nautical miles (740 kilometers) east of Luzon, making it the tropical cyclone with the lowest sea-level pressure recorded globally at the time, until it was surpassed by Typhoon Ida's 877 hPa in 1958. Later on the evening of August 18 to early August 19, the typhoon made landfall or brushed past the northeastern coast of Luzon, where Aparri recorded a minimum pressure of 969.9 hPa (727.5 mmHg). After passing through Luzon, the typhoon entered the northern South China Sea, and at 6 a.m. on August 19, it was located near the northern coast of Luzon, moving in a west-northwest to northwest direction. At 6 a.m. on August 20, the center was northwest of Pratas Island, passing within 10 nautical miles of the island, where winds reached force 11 and the pressure dropped to 967.1 hPa (725.42 mmHg). The typhoon subsequently passed south of Hong Kong and Macau. During the storm, Hong Kong recorded a minimum sea-level pressure of 982.4 hPa, an average wind speed of 98 km/h (53 knots), and gusts of 187 km/h (101 knots). In Macau, the pressure dropped to a minimum of 974.1 hPa (730.6 mmHg), with average wind speeds and gusts reaching 135 km/h and 190 km/h, respectively. Later on the evening of August 20 to August 21, the typhoon made landfall in western Guangdong and gradually dissipated.

The typhoon passed 95 kilometers (60 nautical miles) south of Hong Kong, causing certain damages. Many houses in the Kowloon area collapsed, including over 130 houses in Cheung Sha Wan, and all the squatter huts in Kowloon Tong were blown away. A bus overturned on Salisbury Road. Additionally, 2 ocean-going vessels and 9 fishing boats were damaged. The storm resulted in 15 deaths and 22 injuries. [10][11][12]

In Joaquim Baião Simões' book "Macau and the Typhoons" (1985) [14], it records the typhoon on August 20, 1927, which caused loss of life and immeasurable damage in Macau. The cruiser "Democrata," anchored in the Inner Harbor, nearly sank, and the Governor's Palace was also damaged [3]. The Chinese newspaper reported four drowning deaths [2]. After the storm, the South Bay shoreline was in ruins, with wreckage of numerous fishing boats washed up along the embankment. In the area of Sá Lei Tau, a shipyard was blown down, and on Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro and near the Military Club, large trees were uprooted.

Article_Name: 己巳風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Ji Si Typhoon occurred on August 22-23, 1929, when a severe typhoon directly struck Hong Kong and Macau, causing both places to hoist the only No. 7 signal of that year (equivalent to today's No. 10 signal). In Hong Kong, during the period when the gale signal was hoisted, the Observatory recorded hurricane-force winds for one hour, leading the Observatory to skip the No. 6 signal and directly hoist the No. 7 signal. This was the first time the Observatory had done so since the establishment of the gale enhancement signal.

According to the 1985 publication "Macau and Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)" by the Macau Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau, this storm formed on August 21 in the southeastern waters of the Dongsha Islands, reached its peak on August 22, made landfall, and dissipated on August 23. According to reports from Hong Kong newspapers at the time, the Hong Kong Observatory believed that the storm formed on the afternoon of August 20 at 19 degrees north latitude, approximately 159 miles west of northern Luzon, and moved northwestward. By 2 a.m. on August 21, it shifted northward and passed east of Dongsha Island at 2 p.m. the same day before turning northwest. By 1:30 p.m. on August 22, the storm had reached south of Hong Kong, made landfall near Macau, moved inland, and dissipated. [1]

The storm was closest to Macau on August 22. "Macau and Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)" records that this storm passed through Macau, causing significant impact on the city. During the storm, Macau recorded the highest gusts reaching 220 kilometers per hour (data unverified).

Article_Name: 癸亥風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Guihai Typhoon occurred on August 18, 1923. On that day, a typhoon passed north of Macau and subsequently entered mainland China, causing significant damage. It marked the second time that year that hurricane signals were hoisted in both Hong Kong and Macau, and it was also the longest-lasting hurricane warning in Macau's history. The Central Meteorological Bureau designated this typhoon as B102.

The typhoon that caused this disaster was first observed southwest of Guam on August 11, moving in a northwesterly direction. In the following days, it moved westward. On August 16, the typhoon moved westward at 13 knots (24 kilometers per hour). That evening at 8 PM, the ship Steel Traveler entered the typhoon's center near 21°N, 123.2°E, where the uncorrected sea-level pressure dropped to 711.2 mmHg (948 hPa), and two hours of calm winds were recorded, indicating that its intensity had reached typhoon level. On August 17, the typhoon passed north of Batanes in the early morning, entered the South China Sea, and moved west-northwest at a speed of 17.5 knots (32 kilometers per hour). On the morning of August 18, the typhoon's center passed a few miles south of Hong Kong and around 12 PM passed about 10 miles (approximately 20 kilometers) north of Macau, then moved into mainland China and gradually dissipated.
The storm swept across the southern sea of Taiwan, with wind speeds in Kaohsiung reaching 54 kilometers per hour at one point.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 typhoon signal at 11:25 a.m. on August 17 and the No. 2 typhoon signal at 4:30 p.m. However, the weather in most parts of Hong Kong remained fine for the day, with pressure dropping and cloud cover increasing after nightfall. On August 18, the typhoon moved closer to Hong Kong. The Observatory hoisted the No. 6 typhoon signal at 8:23 a.m., and strong winds began to blow in Hong Kong from 9 a.m., prompting the Observatory to hoist the No. 7 typhoon signal at 9 a.m. Hurricane-force winds were recorded in Hong Kong at 10 a.m., with the typhoon's center passing a few miles south of Hong Kong. The lowest pressure recorded in Hong Kong was 971.7 hPa, with the highest hourly sustained wind speed reaching 72 knots (133 km/h) and gusts of 113 knots (209 km/h). Shortly after, the wind direction shifted to east-southeast, and wind speeds rapidly decreased as the typhoon moved away, with strong winds lasting only three hours.

The storm caused severe casualties and damage in Hong Kong, with storm surges occurring in the harbor. The sea surface suffered significant damage, and the harbor recorded a sea level rise of 3.2 meters, while Tai Po recorded a storm surge height of 4.57 meters. At least 100 people died, including at least 40 fishermen, and one person went missing. The massive waves caused destruction to both the sea and coastal areas. The British Navy submarine HMS L9 was swept out of the naval dockyard by the waves, destroying the dockyard's outer wall before sinking near the Star Ferry Pier on the Hong Kong side. A steamship traveling between China and India was swept by the waves from Kowloon Bay to the Yau Ma Tei pier, where it sank. Along the coastline from Shau Kei Wan to Stonecutters Island, 20 ships were washed ashore, some severely damaged, with at least two fatalities. Ninety percent of the ships docked at the Taikoo Dockyard sank, resulting in significant losses. In the Shau Kei Wan typhoon shelter, over 300 sailing boats or sampans sank, were damaged, or were stranded. In Causeway Bay, some sampans were even thrown onto the roads. In Yau Ma Tei, eight sampans were piled onto the seawall, with two thrown onto land. The waves also destroyed a monument standing off the coast of Hong Kong, damaged the wooden planks of the Central Blake Pier, deformed parts of the Star Ferry Pier's floors, and overturned the asphalt on Connaught Road.

In Tai Po, the storm surge caused severe damage to the coastline. The seawall near the railway in the Tolo Harbour area was destroyed, disrupting train services. A 40-foot embankment at Tai Po Kau pier was destroyed. Several embankments in Sha Tin were washed away, destroying rice crops. A family of six in the area was struck by the storm surge, resulting in four deaths. Tai O experienced even stronger winds, with 12 houses and 19 huts collapsing, though no fatalities were reported. The storm also temporarily disrupted the ongoing East Reclamation Project along the waterfront. After the storm, the reclaimed soil was washed away, but it did not flow into the sea, so the overall impact on the project was minimal.

Affected by the typhoon, the Portuguese Navy hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 11 at 10:30 a.m. on August 18 and lowered it at midnight the following day, lasting 13 and a half hours, the longest on record. During the storm, Macau recorded a minimum pressure of 963.7 hPa, an average wind speed of 115 km/h, and a maximum gust speed of 200 km/h. According to Joaquim Baião Simões' book "Macau and the Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)," the typhoon caused significant damage to Macau, destroying and damaging about 200 houses and 24 shipyards, with 50 various types of ships sunk. The disaster resulted in over 400 deaths and 52 injuries in Macau.

Whole_Text.content: The Jiashen Typhoon (English: 1944 Macau Typhoon) was a tropical cyclone in the 1944 Pacific typhoon season and one of the four typhoons that directly struck Macau in the 1940s.

In the early hours of July 22, due to the impact of the typhoon, it began raining in Hong Kong accompanied by strong winds. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Marine Department hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 2, marking the first time this signal was hoisted since the simplification of the typhoon signal system on October 20, 1943. After the hoisting of Signal No. 2, three ferry routes between Central and Heung To, Tai Kok, and Castle Peak were suspended starting in the morning until the signal was lowered. Regarding land transportation, only passenger bicycles and rickshaws continued to operate in the wind and rain. Businesses along both sides of Victoria Harbour closed their doors and windows tightly, pedestrians were sparse, the streets were quiet, and many shop signs fell. Around 8 a.m., a floating corpse was discovered near the Central Keng Shan Pier, suspected to be a victim of a sunken boat, which was later swept away by the waves. The doors and windows of a shop along the waterfront in Chung Sum Yat Tong were destroyed by the wind, and one vacant building each on First Street in the Water City District and Gaham Street in Central collapsed, causing no casualties. The district officer of the lowland area toured the streets in the wind and rain with an administrative officer in the morning, giving instructions to citizens on typhoon precautions. By noon, the wind and rain had weakened, and the Marine Department lowered Typhoon Signal No. 2 in the afternoon. The "Hong Kong Maru," originally scheduled to depart from Hong Kong to Guangdong Province at 8 p.m., had to be delayed by a day due to the still-strong winds. Prices rose significantly due to the typhoon's impact on supply, with the price of rice increasing from HK$7.2 per catty on July 21 to a peak of HK$8 on the 22nd. Sweet potatoes rose from HK$2.9 per catty on the eve of the storm to over HK$3, and the supply of fish and vegetables was tight, with prices also increasing.

At 11 a.m. on July 20, the Macau Meteorological Department learned of very low pressure in the northern South China Sea and the appearance of a tropical cyclone. They immediately ordered the hoisting of Signal No. 1 at the Guia Fortress, the Maritime Administration, and the Guia Lighthouse. On the afternoon of July 21, the weather in Macau deteriorated with heavy rain, and at around 7 p.m., Signal No. 5 was hoisted, warning of possible strong northwest winds. The city experienced strong winds and rain, and ferry services between the Macau Peninsula and Taipa were suspended. Ships sought shelter in the Inner Harbour typhoon shelter. At around 2 a.m. on July 22, the winds intensified, and Signal No. 9 was hoisted. The Maritime Administration's rescue ferry ventured out to patrol the Outer Harbour in case of emergencies. At around 7 a.m. on July 22, the typhoon appeared to be directly impacting Macau. At 8:30 a.m., the Meteorological Department ordered the replacement of Signal No. 9 with Signal No. 10, the first in three years. The Guia Fortress fired three cannon shots to warn of the approaching hurricane. Macau experienced a day of strong winds and heavy rain, with the Outer Harbour area being the most threatened. However, as the typhoon quickly passed south of Macau without directly crossing it, overall damage was minimal. An unmanned boat sank at sea, the New Reclamation swimming area was destroyed, the Nam Van Friendship Stadium was damaged, and many rooftop clothes-drying racks and shop signs were blown away. Several small trees on Avenida de Venceslau de Morais were uprooted. A shipyard in the Areia Preta area collapsed, causing significant cargo losses but no casualties. Streets such as Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro, Rua da Felicidade, Rua dos Mercadores, Rua da Praia do Manduco, and the San Kio district were flooded, with water levels exceeding one foot in some areas. Several old houses on Avenida do Almirante Lacerda collapsed, injuring a police officer. By midday on July 22, the winds weakened and shifted to a southerly direction. At 12:50 p.m., the Guia Fortress fired two cannon shots to signal the end of the hurricane threat, and Signal No. 6 was hoisted. At 7 p.m., Signal No. 1 was hoisted again, and all signals were removed before midnight.

Article_Name: 2018年寿光洪灾 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2018 Shouguang flood disaster refers to the flood disaster that occurred in Shouguang City, Weifang, Shandong Province, China, from August 19 to 21, 2018, caused by heavy rain and concentrated reservoir discharges upstream of the Mi River, resulting in flooding in the Shouguang section of the Mi River. From August 19 to 20, under the influence of tropical storm Rumbia, the Mi River basin in Shandong experienced extremely heavy rainfall, causing water levels to rise significantly in the Yeyuan Reservoir, Tangshuya Reservoir, and Heihushan Reservoir in Qingzhou and Linqu, leading to reservoir discharges. Although the reservoirs provided some warnings to downstream villagers, the time was only sufficient for residents to evacuate, leaving livestock and property behind. This event caused the Shouguang section of the Mi River to experience the largest flood peak since 1974, with multiple villages along the Shouguang riverbanks suffering from river water backflow, resulting in the destruction of numerous homes, farmland, greenhouses, and farms, and potentially affecting the stability of vegetable supply to Beijing. During the same period as the Shouguang flood disaster, there was a continuous rise in vegetable prices nationwide, which drew attention from Xinhua News Agency. According to official statistics, as of 5 p.m. on the 23rd, the disaster caused 13 deaths, 3 missing persons, the collapse of 9,999 houses, and economic losses of approximately 9.2 billion yuan. Since the number of collapsed houses exceeded 10,000, the government was required to initiate a national level-4 response. The figure of 9,999 collapsed houses was questioned for being overly coincidental, raising suspicions of falsification. Phoenix News published an article titled "Shouguang Flood Disaster: 9,999 Houses Damaged, Where Are the Facts?" questioning the data from the People's Daily client on August 23, which reported "10,335 houses collapsed, 8,240 houses severely damaged, and 53,465 houses generally damaged." The article was later deleted.
