Article_Name: 2018年8月下旬臺灣暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The late August 2018 Taiwan heavy rain refers to the natural disaster caused by intense rainfall from August 23 to August 30, 2018, due to the convergence of a tropical depression and the southwest monsoon, as well as the subsequent development of a large low-pressure zone lingering over South China after the system dissipated, which brought further southwest airflow. Areas such as Yunlin, Chiayi, Nantou, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung experienced widespread flooding, with some localized areas remaining flooded for nearly a week. It was the most severe and prolonged catastrophic heavy rain to affect Taiwan since the Typhoon Morakot disaster. President Tsai Ing-wen of the Republic of China specifically instructed Presidential Office Secretary-General Chen Chu to stay in Kaohsiung to oversee disaster response efforts in southern Taiwan.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation pointed out on the 25th that Taiwan is within a low-pressure zone, influenced by the low-pressure zone and southwesterly airflow, which contributed to this heavy rain event. The Weather Bureau also continued to issue land strong wind warnings and heavy rain warnings for certain areas, reminding the public of potential landslides, falling rocks, debris flows, flash floods, and flooding before the southwesterly airflow affected Taiwan. The Weather Risk Management Development Company stated that compared to the impact of the previous tropical depression, the rainfall brought by this heavy rain event was relatively moderate. The Central Disaster Response Center, established in response to the tropical depression, was dismantled at 7 PM on the 25th and reopened three hours later to address this heavy rain event. Premier Lai Ching-te inspected the Central Disaster Response Center on the 28th and emphasized the importance of strengthening horizontal communication between ministries and vertical cooperation with local governments to help residents return home as soon as possible.  

Due to the continued impact of heavy rain, the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued an extremely heavy rain warning for Pingtung County on the evening of the 27th and heavy rain warnings for Tainan City, Kaohsiung City, and Taitung County. The extremely heavy rain warning was extended to Kaohsiung City the following day. The Soil and Water Conservation Bureau of the Council of Agriculture also issued 42 red alerts for debris flows on the morning of the 28th, covering 6 townships and 15 villages in Kaohsiung and Pingtung, and 166 yellow alerts for areas including Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, and Taitung. They urged local governments to advise or force residents to evacuate and provide proper resettlement. The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs issued a level-one flood warning for 13 districts in Kaohsiung City and 5 townships in Pingtung County.

Affected by the heavy rain event, the Kaohsiung City Government stated that the city has emptied all detention basins and artificial lakes to facilitate water storage and established a Level 1 Disaster Response Center at 6:30 PM that evening. The Agriculture and Food Agency of the Council of Agriculture called on farmers to harvest crops that are ready for harvest in a timely manner to reduce losses. The Fisheries Agency of the Council of Agriculture also urged fishermen to take advantage of breaks in the rain to implement disaster prevention measures. The Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs issued a Level 1 flood warning at 6:27 AM on the 28th for 13 districts in Kaohsiung City and 5 towns in Pingtung County. 

The Xiaoliuqiu to Donggang ferry route was also affected by the heavy rain event, with reduced services on the 26th and suspension on the 27th, during which 2,500 people returned to Donggang before noon on the 26th. Ferries from Taitung to Lanyu and Green Island were also suspended on the 27th, leaving nearly 4,000 tourists stranded. The Maritime and Port Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications estimated that 58 ferry trips would be canceled on the 28th due to the heavy rain event.

The Southern Region Water Resources Office of the Water Resources Agency stated that in response to the second wave of heavy rain, Zengwen Reservoir and Mudan Reservoir were both undergoing regulated discharges on the morning of the 27th. It also mentioned that Agongdian Reservoir is currently in an empty reservoir sediment prevention period. To prepare for the potential rainfall brought by this wave of heavy rain, the Southern Region Water Resources Office conducted regulated water releases to reserve flood detention space.

This southwest airflow brought heavy rain to Pingtung County, with Xinyuan Township recording over 300 millimeters of rainfall from midnight to 11:30 a.m. on August 28, ranking first in Taiwan. On the same day, Kaohsiung City also recorded over 300 millimeters of daily rainfall. The intense rainfall caused slippery roads in many areas, leading to multiple traffic accidents. In Xinyuan Township, Pingtung County, a car crashed into a utility pole, resulting in one death and three injuries. In Zhuqi Township, Chiayi County, a car collision, possibly due to slippery roads and poor visibility caused by the rain, resulted in one death and one serious injury. On the 26th, the Pingtung County Police Department reported that a 64-year-old man went to Haishen Temple in Sandimen Township but was found missing after his car door was left open and the right rear wheel was stuck in the riverbed, marking the first missing person case in this heavy rain event.

The heavy rain also affected provincial highways. At the 260-kilometer mark of the Taiwan Route 17 in Qianzai Kou, water accumulation exceeded 20 centimeters and stretched over 100 meters. The Third Engineering Office of the Directorate General of Highways implemented road closures on the morning of the 26th. According to the Pingtung County Disaster Response Center, the Wutan section of the Ping 106 line in Taiwu Township was preemptively closed due to landslide risks. On the 1-kilometer mark of the 200A line in Manzhou Township, landslides obstructed road drainage, leading to controlled traffic. Additionally, the drainage system on the Fangliao section of Taiwan Route 1 was overwhelmed, causing approximately 20 centimeters of water accumulation on the road.

Whole_Text.header: Announce the suspension of work and classes controversy

Whole_Text.content: Pingtung County Magistrate Pan Meng-an stated on the evening of the 26th that Pingtung County, based on the Central Weather Bureau's forecast, announced the suspension of work and classes on the 27th. At the same time, it also became one of the counties and cities in the 2018 Republic of China local public office elections to stop accepting candidate registrations. This move raised questions from netizens about the standards for declaring holidays in Pingtung County. Pingtung County Government Personnel Office Director Li Yin-ming emphasized that the weather forecast had reached the standard for suspending work and classes and stated that the top ten rainfall amounts on that day were all within Pingtung County. On the evening of the 27th, the Pingtung County Government announced that a landslide occurred in Shiwen Village and a collapse on County Road 146, causing traffic disruptions. Therefore, only Shiwen Village in Chunri Township, Pingtung County, would suspend work and classes on the 28th. The next day, heavy rain continued to fall in Pingtung County, with daily rainfall in several towns exceeding 200 millimeters. Severe traffic congestion occurred on the Linluo section of Provincial Highway 1 due to water accumulation, and flooding was reported on Guangfu Road near Pingtung Station and Fuxing South Road in Pingtung City, leading residents to question the county government's decision-making. Pingtung residents pointed out that the rainfall in Pingtung was no less than that in Kaohsiung, yet Pingtung County had normal work and classes on the 28th. They further stated that the Pingtung County Government should prioritize public safety. Pingtung County Government spokesperson Huang Jian-jia apologized in the afternoon, explaining that the rain was concentrated in a few towns and that widespread flooding had not occurred in the early morning.

The Kaohsiung City Government stated on the evening of the 26th that, based on rainfall observation data released by the Central Weather Bureau, work and classes in Kaohsiung City would proceed as usual on the 27th. However, netizens discovered that Acting Mayor Hsu Li-ming had mistakenly posted the quantitative precipitation forecast from the Weather Bureau and subsequently deleted the post. In response, the Kaohsiung City Government explained that the previous post was deleted due to an error and not intentionally removed. From the evening of the 27th to the early morning of the 28th, heavy rainfall continued in Kaohsiung City. The Kaohsiung Weather Station of the Weather Bureau also issued a late-night reminder that heavy rainfall radar echoes had entered the Kaohsiung area, urging the public to take disaster prevention measures. Acting Mayor Hsu Li-ming urgently announced at 6 a.m. on the 28th that work and classes would be suspended that day, prompting public outrage with comments such as "You announce it after we've already left home" and "Can I call for a boat on Uber?" This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the public. In response, Hsu Li-ming apologized on Facebook, while his staff noted that he had stayed up all night monitoring the flooding situation.

On August 24, while the entire nation was busy with disaster relief, Vice President of the Republic of China, Chen Chien-jen, took his family to Kinmen for a three-day, two-night vacation, visiting major attractions in both Greater and Lesser Kinmen. He was accompanied by twelve bodyguards, and nearly twenty plainclothes police officers from the Kinmen County Police Bureau were deployed for full-time protection. This incident drew criticism from the public, with Kinmen County legislator Yang Cheng-wu blasting, "He doesn't come when he should, but comes when he shouldn't." Presidential Office spokesperson Alex Huang stated that as a member of the government team, causing negative public perception and criticism of the team made Vice President Chen feel deeply regretful, and he extended his apologies to the public. This incident was compared by the public to the actions of former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who took time for a haircut before the 2009 Typhoon Morakot disaster, and former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsueh Hsiang-chuan, who had sweet potato porridge with his father-in-law after working overtime, both of whom were criticized by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) until they stepped down, highlighting a stark contrast.

On August 25, 2018, President Tsai Ing-wen of the Republic of China, accompanied by Chiayi County Magistrate Helen Chang, rode a Clouded Leopard armored vehicle to inspect Budai Township. Smiling, she encouraged disaster victims to stay strong. However, after traveling only about 50 meters, the vehicle was stopped by local residents who angrily shouted, "If you drive further, just run me over!" Kuomintang spokesperson Hung Meng-kai harshly criticized the incident on Facebook as "the most arrogant disaster inspection in history," likening Tsai Ing-wen to a "beauty queen on a parade float." Citizens also vented their anger on Facebook, questioning, "Disaster inspection? You won't even step into the water for a show, and you come in an armored vehicle? At least pretend to be solemn or reflective! Smiling? Waving? Are you here to thank voters or campaign? Are you sure you're not in the wrong place?" 

Several public figures criticized the incident. Chu Hsueh-heng condemned Tsai Ing-wen for continuously smiling and waving from various angles and at different times, saying, "Her smile sends chills down your spine." Chu remarked that Tsai, who once held others to strict standards, is now being judged by the same standards, stating, "If karma strikes, let it strike. Is it so hard to avoid double standards?" Hu You-wei commented that the incident occurred in Yong'an Village, symbolizing that Tsai can no longer "stay safe forever." He humorously expressed Tsai's sentiments, saying, "Whoever came up with the bad idea of having the president inspect disaster areas in an armored vehicle, send them to the Ministry of Punishments for 80 lashes and then to the labor camp to clean toilets." 

Chang San-cheng pointed out, "The people feel no empathy from the government. They've been soaking in water for days and hope high-ranking officials can understand their pain, but instead, they see President Tsai riding an armored vehicle, 'aloof and detached'!" He criticized Tsai for failing to "share the people's suffering," lamenting, "With a president like this, I truly feel sorrow for our country." 

Qiu Yi-ying criticized Kuomintang Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Han Kuo-yu for attending a campaign song release event for a city council candidate, saying, "Kaohsiung residents don't need a mayoral candidate like this!" 

Subsequently, on August 26, Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Tsai Chi-chang led legislators Lee Chun-yi, Ho Hsin-chun, Chiu Yi-ying, Lin Ching-yi, Lee Li-fen, Chou Chun-mi, and Chang Liao Wan-chien on a visit to Poland's parliament. This sparked controversy, as some questioned the appropriateness of the trip while flood disaster relief in affected areas was still incomplete. 

On August 28, 2018, Legislative Yuan Speaker Su Jia-chyuan was spotted in Japan by the public, raising suspicions of a leisure trip. Legislative Yuan Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia stated that Su was invited by the Japanese government for an official visit, accompanied by his wife. However, due to concerns about Taiwan's disaster situation, Su returned to Taiwan early that day.

Article_Name: 八七水災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The August 7 Flood was a severe flood that occurred in southern and central Taiwan from August 7 to August 9, 1959. It is the second most impactful disaster in terms of affected areas and number of victims in Taiwan since the post-war period, following the 1999 "921 Earthquake" and the 2009 "August 8 Flood." The death toll (including missing persons) ranks second only to the 1999 "921 Earthquake" among major disasters.

On August 6, 1959, a tropical depression formed over the sea near Dongsha Island and moved northeastward, gradually approaching Taiwan, but it did not further develop into a tropical storm. On August 7, Typhoon Ellen over the southern seas of Japan, due to the Fujiwhara effect, drew the tropical depression near Dongsha Island (081) into Taiwan. At 5 p.m. on August 7, the tropical depression made landfall in Budai Township, Chiayi County. After landfall, it gradually weakened due to the influence of the terrain and dissipated near Puli Township due to the obstruction of the Central Mountain Range. It then induced a secondary low-pressure system between Hualien and Xincheng on the eastern side of the Central Mountain Range and continued moving north-northeastward. During its movement over Taiwan, this tropical depression caused extremely unstable weather in central and southern Taiwan, forming a strong southwest airflow and triggering torrential rain.  

The heavy rain began around 6 p.m. on August 7 and eased by the afternoon of August 8. The southwestern slopes of the central and southern mountainous regions and the adjacent western plains recorded rainfall exceeding 500 millimeters. From August 7 to 9, the cumulative rainfall in central and southern Taiwan reached 800 to 1,200 millimeters over three consecutive days—particularly on August 7, when the daily rainfall reached 500 to 1,000 millimeters, nearly equivalent to the average annual rainfall. There were 15 locations where daily rainfall exceeded 500 millimeters. The main centers of heavy rain were concentrated in Miaoli, Fengyuan, Fenyuan, the upper reaches of the Wu River, Douliu, and Alishan.  

Due to the difficulty in draining surface water and the occurrence of flash floods, river levels rose and breached dikes. The flooding destroyed houses and farmland, resulting in an unprecedented flood disaster. The affected areas included all agricultural regions of Taiwan, with extremely severe damage.

The disaster area of the August 7 Flood covered 13 counties and cities, with Miaoli County, Taichung County, Nantou County, Changhua County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, and Taichung City being the most severely affected. Among these, the Dadu River (Wu River) basin experienced heavy rainfall in its upstream tributaries on the evening of the 7th, causing the river to rise rapidly. Floodwaters surged southward, but due to the narrow waterway near the Changhua Railway Bridge, the water could not be discharged in time. This resulted in the left bank of the Dadu River being breached for 1,102 meters, flooding Changhua City, Hemei Township, and Shengang Township, making them the areas with the most severe damage. On the morning of the 8th, floodwaters entered Changhua City, reaching their peak at noon with water depths of up to 3 meters in the shallowest areas. The floodwaters began to recede afterward, with the city center clearing by the morning of the 9th, while the outskirts remained flooded until the afternoon of the 9th.

The upper reaches of the Beigang River received the highest rainfall during the August 7 Flood, causing the river to overflow its banks and flood areas such as Huwei, Douliu, Dapi, Douliu, Tuku, and Beigang, resulting in severe damage. In Miaoli County, the Tana Ba River experienced a sudden rise in water levels on the morning of the 8th, breaching the Wuhu embankment and turning Xihu Township into a vast expanse of water. In the southern region, rivers such as the Bajhang River, Jishui River, Zengwen River, and Yanshui River also overflowed their banks, causing widespread flooding in areas including Shuishang Township, Yanshui Township, Xuejia Township, Madou Township, Xinshi Township, Yongkang Township, and parts of Tainan City.

The actual disaster area covered 1,365 square kilometers, affecting over 300,000 residents. The death toll reached 667, with 408 missing and 942 injured. A total of 27,466 houses were completely destroyed, and 18,303 were partially destroyed. Transportation and communication in the disaster areas were almost entirely cut off, with over 130,000 hectares of farmland damaged. The total loss was estimated at NT$3.7 billion, accounting for approximately 12% of the previous year's gross national income.

Due to the severe disaster, the military stationed on the island was quickly dispatched for disaster relief following the President's orders. The government of the Republic of China also mobilized citizens to assist in disaster relief based on the "National Obligatory Labor Act," and the Taiwan Provincial Government distributed relief funds to disaster victims according to the "Taiwan Provincial People's Relief Measures for Disaster-related Deaths, Injuries, and Housing Collapses." Then-President Chiang Kai-shek issued an emergency order to levy a flood reconstruction donation to raise funds for rebuilding. 

As for foreign aid, the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command (USTDC) immediately deployed three U.S. Navy helicopters for disaster relief after the disaster. A few days later, Washington ordered the helicopter carrier USS Thetis Bay (CVE-90) to redirect from Hong Kong waters, carrying 21 Sikorsky H-34 helicopters from the U.S. Marine Corps HMR(L)-261 squadron to Taiwan for disaster relief. The mission was named "Operation Hunger."

Article_Name: 1870年长江洪水 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 1870 Yangtze River flood was a catastrophic flood that occurred in the Yangtze River basin during June of the ninth year of the Tongzhi era (Gengwu year) in the Qing Dynasty. The provinces of Sichuan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi, and Anhui were affected, and the disaster was unprecedented in several hundred years. As it occurred in the Gengwu year, it was called the Gengwu Disaster.

In July 1870, as heavy rain entered the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, the Jialing River experienced a rare major flood. Based on water marks, the peak flow at Beibei Station was estimated to reach 57,300 cubic meters per second (the 1981 flood flow was 44,700 cubic meters per second). The major flood of the Jialing River and the Jinsha River flood converged in Chongqing, forming an extraordinary flood in the main stream of the Yangtze River. The water level at Cuntan Station reached 196.15 meters, with a peak flow of 100,000 cubic meters per second (the 1981 peak water level was 191.42 meters, with a flow of 85,700 cubic meters per second). According to records from Wanxian, the estimated 30-day flood volume was approximately 165 billion cubic meters. At Yichang, the flow was about 105,000 cubic meters per second. After the Qingjiang River joined, the peak flow at Zhicheng Station reached 110,000 cubic meters per second. 

In the northern Jingjiang area below Jianli, multiple breaches occurred, turning the Jianghan Plain into a vast expanse of water. On the southern bank of the Yangtze River, the dike at Songzi breached, creating a new Songzi River that directly discharged into Dongting Lake, leaving houses and farmland along the way completely destroyed. Modern scholars, based on stone inscriptions in places like Baxian, determined that the flood occurred from the 13th to the 21st of June. After the flood, Sichuan Governor Wu Tang reported the disaster situation in eastern Sichuan. On the Renchen day in July, the Qing court responded, instructing Wu Tang to handle the disaster together with the provincial administration and dismissing Xu Junyong, the magistrate of Fengdu County, from his position.

In 1952, the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission conducted an investigation into this flood and concluded that it was the largest flood among the eight major historical floods of the Yangtze River from 1153 to the end of the 20th century, as well as among the five major floods measured in the 20th century.

Article_Name: 2021年8月河南暴雨 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The heavy rainstorm in Henan in August 2021 refers to the large-scale, persistent, and intense rainfall process dominated by the Huanghuai cyclone, which occurred from August 21, 2021, in Henan Province of the People's Republic of China and surrounding areas in North China. Since it occurred after the severe Henan flood disaster in July 2021 and multiple meteorological agencies and numerical models indicated an extreme trend in this round of rainfall, it received high attention and vigilance from all sectors in Henan. Before the arrival of the heavy rain, the Zhengzhou municipal government took preventive measures by preemptively releasing water from reservoirs across the city, and several public transportation services were suspended due to the impact of this event.

According to China Weather Network, starting from the afternoon of August 22, the rainfall intensity in Henan Province of the People's Republic of China significantly increased, and Zhengzhou issued the highest-level red alert for heavy rain. Between 12:00 and 15:00, torrential rain poured in local areas such as Pingdingshan, Jiaozuo, and Zhengzhou. The maximum three-hour rainfall was recorded at 138.1 mm in Ligou Village, Lushan County, Pingdingshan City, while the maximum hourly rainfall intensity was 80.4 mm in the same location. China Weather Network warned that all regions should also be alert to gusts with expected intensities reaching levels 7-9 accompanying the rainfall.

Chen Tao, chief forecaster of the National Meteorological Center, explained that from the perspective of system configuration, this heavy rainfall process is a typical monsoon rainfall. The westward extension of the subtropical high allowed warm and moist airflows from the Indian Ocean, South China Sea, and Western Pacific to move smoothly northward along the western edge of the subtropical high, confronting cold air from the north, resulting in a widespread rainfall process. "Simply put, the cold air from the north and the southwest monsoon airflow clashed, collided, and interacted in the southwest region and the Huanghuai area, forming a 'volatile' low vortex and cyclone weather system." Zhang Tao believed that this heavy rain process in Henan was different from the "7.20" event. This rainfall process was mobile and would not replicate the "stagnation" of the July Henan flood disaster, so the cumulative rainfall would not be particularly extreme.

Before the heavy rain occurred, the Central Meteorological Observatory once issued a forecast indicating that an extreme heavy rainstorm with a daily rainfall of 400mm would occur near the urban area of Zhengzhou. According to a report by the Global Times, the Henan Expressway Management Brigade stated in a notice that from the night of August 21 to the 22nd, due to the complex road conditions on the Gongyi section of the Lianhuo Expressway, the northbound lanes from k621 to k632 would be reduced from four lanes to two lanes. At the same time, drivers were reminded to avoid traveling on this section unless necessary, and control measures would be implemented promptly based on weather conditions.

According to CCTV News, on the evening of August 21, many residents in Zhengzhou parked their private cars on elevated bridges to cope with potential extreme heavy rainfall. In response, the Zhengzhou traffic police stated: "The traffic police department will not treat vehicles temporarily parked on roads, elevated bridges, etc., for emergency flood prevention as violations. We remind citizens to park their vehicles in a way that does not affect road traffic as much as possible and to move their vehicles to locations that do not obstruct traffic promptly after the heavy rain subsides."  

At noon on August 22, the Zhengzhou City Flood Control Office issued a notice requiring the implementation of traffic control and closure measures for 67 urban bridge culverts and tunnels and 23 small railway bridge culverts. Zhengzhou traffic police announced that entrances and exits of tunnels such as the Jingguang Tunnel (south, central, and north sections), Future Road Tunnel, and Hongzhuan Road Tunnel have been closed, with personnel stationed on duty. As the rainfall intensified, Zhengzhou traffic police deployed officers to key intersections and road sections, including culverts, bridges, water accumulation points, and underpasses, to carry out traffic security work. Depending on the rainfall, they set up warning tapes, placed warning signs and reflective cones, and fully cooperated with relevant departments in drainage and emergency rescue operations.  

According to CCTV News, China Railway Zhengzhou Group Co., Ltd. suspended 59 passenger trains for one day starting from midnight on August 22, including 14 direct passenger trains and 45 regional passenger trains.  

The official Weibo account of Zhengzhou Public Transport Corporation announced that, according to Order No. 6 of the Zhengzhou Flood Control and Drought Relief Command, all bus routes in Zhengzhou would cease operation on August 22 and August 23.  

On August 21, the Flood Control and Drought Relief Command of Xinzheng City, under the jurisdiction of Zhengzhou, issued an emergency notice stating that from 6:00 PM on August 21 to 12:00 PM on August 23, the city would implement emergency evacuation measures. Except for rescue and livelihood security personnel, all work, classes, production, business, and transportation in the city would be suspended. Enterprises unable to suspend work or production temporarily due to special reasons must report to the city's Flood Control and Drought Relief Command and take appropriate emergency precautions.  

According to the official Weibo account of the Publicity Department of the CPC Xingyang Municipal Committee, Xingyang City authorities initiated a Level I flood control response starting at 2:00 PM on August 21, 2021. All enterprises involving high temperatures and high pressure were required to suspend production; all outdoor work was halted; all street-facing shops and underground malls were closed; all public transportation was suspended; and all scenic spots, hazardous roads, and underground culverts in the jurisdiction were closed. Residents living in areas prone to flash floods, geological disasters, downstream of dangerous reservoirs and silt dams, low-lying flood-prone areas, and damaged houses were required to evacuate in advance and relocate to safe areas.  

According to CCTV News, as of 5:21 PM Beijing time on August 22, Zhengzhou had activated a Level II flood control response. So far, 240,000 people in Zhengzhou have been urgently evacuated to avoid risks.

According to the Global Times, in response to the possible extreme heavy rainfall, all regular-speed trains and high-speed trains in Jiaozuo city were suspended for one day on August 22; taxis, passenger bus lines, and tourist transportation were all suspended.

The authorities of Weihui City issued a notice before the heavy rain, stating that from August 22 to August 23, Weihui City would experience a heavy rainfall process, with localized areas reaching extremely heavy rainstorms, accompanied by winds of 7-9 levels. The rainfall is expected to reach 250mm to 400mm. The authorities required that no one is allowed to stay in any dangerous buildings and issued a series of disaster prevention instructions. [8]

The Xun County authorities issued a notice stating that, according to the provincial and municipal flood control headquarters, there will be heavy to torrential rain in the northern Henan region on August 22, with expected rainfall in some areas of the county reaching 250-400 millimeters. To prevent risks caused by flooding or overflow of embankments due to the rainfall, the Xun County Gongquxi flood detention area will initiate flood diversion, and all personnel within the flood detention area are instructed to complete evacuation by 6 p.m. today.

Starting from 2 a.m. on August 23, heavy rain fell across Xuzhou. As of 8 a.m., the city's average rainfall reached 98mm, approaching the level of a torrential rain. Among them, Xinyi recorded 111mm, Jiawang 116.8mm, Pizhou 134.8mm, and Tongshan 136.4mm, all reaching the torrential rain level. The rainfall in Xuzhou's urban area reached 135.4mm, also reaching the torrential rain level. Due to the heavy rain, severe waterlogging occurred in many areas of the city.

According to a report published by Jining News Network, supervised by the Jining Municipal Party Committee Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party, heavy to torrential rain and localized extreme torrential rain occurred in the southeastern region of Shandong on August 23, while the peninsula region experienced moderate to heavy rain with localized torrential or extreme torrential rain. In some areas of southeastern Shandong and the Shandong Peninsula, easterly gusts of 7 to 10 levels were observed at times. The rainfall at Junan Station exceeded 50 millimeters within three hours, and the heavy rain caused flooding of some crops in Zaozhuang. At 12:00 a.m. on August 24, the Qingdao Natural Resources and Planning Bureau upgraded the geological disaster blue warning issued on August 23 to a yellow warning in some areas of the city (eastern Laoshan District), pointing out that the risk of rainfall-induced geological disasters in eastern Laoshan District was relatively high.

Article_Name: 2020年长江洪水 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2020 Yangtze River floods refer to a series of floods in the Yangtze River basin in China caused by continuous heavy rainfall from June to August 2020. During this period, there were five floods that reached the intensity level for classification, named Yangtze River Flood No. 1 to Yangtze River Flood No. 5.
The 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in June 2020.

The inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second as of 10:00 on July 2. The Ministry of Water Resources of the People's Republic of China, in accordance with the "Regulations on the Numbering of Major Floods in National Rivers," named this flood as the 2020 Yangtze River No. 1 Flood.

Starting from June 29, 2020, the outflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir was controlled at an average of 35,000 cubic meters per second daily to intercept upstream floods and attempt to alleviate downstream flooding. [2] In July 2020, heavy rainfall in the Yangtze River Basin in China showed no signs of abating. The inflow from the main stream of the upper Yangtze River, Wujiang River, and the Three Gorges area significantly increased compared to June. On July 2, 2020, the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir reached 50,000 cubic meters per second. On the same day, the Ministry of Water Resources named this flood the "First Yangtze River Flood of 2020." The Yangtze River Water Resources Commission also initiated a Level IV emergency response for flood and drought disaster prevention on this day. [3] Xinhua News Agency reported that there would be three heavy rainfall events in the Yangtze River Basin in the coming week, with cumulative rainfall in the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, Qingjiang River, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream expected to reach 100 to 150 millimeters. Tributaries in the Xiangxi area, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, the Three Gorges area, Qingjiang River, the middle and lower reaches of the Hanjiang River, the Dongting Lake area, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River's main stream will experience significant water level rises in the coming week. Floods exceeding warning levels may occur in areas near Chenglingji on the Yangtze River's main stream, the middle and lower reaches of the Wujiang River, and some small and medium-sized rivers. [4]

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 2 Flood refers to the flood that occurred under the circumstances of continued increase in water inflow from the upper reaches of the Yangtze River mainstream and the Three Gorges area, with the inflow rate into the Three Gorges Reservoir continuing to rise rapidly. The duration was approximately from July 14, 2020, to July 19, 2020.

At 10:00 on July 17, 2020, the inflow of the Three Gorges Reservoir rose significantly, reaching 50,000 cubic meters per second. According to the flood numbering regulations for major rivers in the People's Republic of China, this inflow met the standard for flood numbering and was designated as the 2020 Yangtze River No. 2 Flood.

Since July 14, 2020, heavy rain or torrential rain has occurred in Sichuan, Chongqing, and other areas. The Three Gorges Reservoir has been holding back floodwaters, and the water level has been continuously rising. At 8:00 PM on July 15, the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir was 28,100 cubic meters per second. On July 17 at 10:00 AM, the inflow reached 50,000 cubic meters per second, the outflow was 32,200 cubic meters per second, and the reservoir water level reached 157.11 meters, exceeding the flood control limit by 12 meters. By 11:00 AM on July 17, the Three Gorges Reservoir had utilized approximately 7 billion cubic meters of flood storage capacity, with about 15 billion cubic meters remaining. At 8:00 AM on July 18, the inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir peaked at 61,000 cubic meters per second, lasting for about 18 hours. The outflow was 33,000 cubic meters per second, with a flood retention rate exceeding 45%. By 8:00 PM on July 19, the inflow had decreased to 46,000 cubic meters per second, a drop of 15,000 cubic meters per second from the peak. According to official reports, the second flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 successfully passed through the Three Gorges Dam.

At 12:00 on July 19, 2020, the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission issued a blue flood warning for the Shashi section of the Yangtze River's middle reaches, upgraded to an orange flood warning for the Chuhe River, and continued to issue orange flood warnings for the main stream of the Yangtze River below Chenglingji, the Dongting Lake area, the Poyang Lake area, and the Shuiyang River. A yellow flood warning was issued for the Shigu section of the Jinsha River, urging relevant units and the public to take precautions.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 3 Flood refers to the flood that occurred under the circumstances of continued increase in water inflow from the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, including the Min River, Jialing River, and the section from Xiangjiaba to Cuntan, as well as the Three Gorges section, with a rapid rise in the inflow rate into the Three Gorges Reservoir.

On July 26, 2020, according to the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources, due to heavy rainfall, the inflow from the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, including the Min River, Jialing River, and the section from Xiangjiaba to Cuntan, as well as the Three Gorges section, significantly increased. The inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir rose rapidly, reaching 50,000 cubic meters per second at 2:00 PM on July 26. According to the "National Major River Flood Numbering Regulations," it met the criteria for flood numbering. This flood was named the "2020 Yangtze River No. 3 Flood." [11]

On July 23, 2020, the Hubei Provincial Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters stated that the third flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 was forming. From 2:00 to 12:00 on July 26, 2020, the inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir rapidly increased from 36,000 cubic meters per second to 50,000 cubic meters per second. On July 27, 2020, at 14:00, the peak flood flow reached 60,000 cubic meters per second, and the Three Gorges Dam reduced the flood peak by 36.7%.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 4 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the tributaries of the upper Yangtze River, including the Tuojiang, Fujiang, Minjiang, and the main stream section from Luzhou to Cuntan.

On August 14, 2020, at 5 a.m., due to heavy rainfall, the tributaries of the upper Yangtze River, Tuojiang and Fujiang, experienced floods exceeding the safety level, and the Minjiang River and the Luzhou to Cuntan section of the main stream experienced floods exceeding the warning level. The flow rate at the Cuntan station on the main stream of the upper Yangtze River rose to 50,900 cubic meters per second, meeting the flood numbering standard according to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations." [14]

At 5:00 on August 14, the Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources officially announced: "The 4th flood of the Yangtze River in 2020" has formed in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River. The peak flow at Cuntan Hydrological Station is expected to be around 58,000 cubic meters per second on the evening of the 14th. The maximum inflow to the Three Gorges Reservoir is expected to reach about 59,000 cubic meters per second at 8:00 on the 15th.

The relevant person in charge of the Ministry of Water Resources stated on August 14 that the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission and related provinces (cities) should strengthen monitoring, forecasting, and early warning, ensure flood control scheduling of key reservoirs such as the Three Gorges, and carry out dike inspections and defense work to ensure flood control safety.

The 2020 Yangtze River No. 5 Flood refers to the flood disaster caused by heavy rainfall in the tributaries of the upper Yangtze River, including the Min River, Tuo River, Jialing River, and Fu River.

At 2:00 PM on August 17, the flow rate at the Cuntan Hydrological Station rose to 20,100 cubic meters per second. According to the "National Major Rivers Flood Numbering Regulations," it reached the standard for flood numbering. The Hydrology Bureau of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission of the Ministry of Water Resources announced the formation of the fifth flood of the Yangtze River in 2020. The maximum inflow rate of the Three Gorges Reservoir is expected to reach approximately 70,000 cubic meters per second on August 19. On August 20, the fifth flood of the Yangtze River in 2020 passed through the central urban area of Chongqing. At 12:00 PM on the 19th, the inflow rate rose to 72,000 cubic meters per second, setting a new record since the construction of the Three Gorges Reservoir. The previous record was 71,200 cubic meters per second on July 24, 2012. On the 20th, the flood peak is expected to reach 75,000 cubic meters per second.

The Ministry of Water Resources recently intensified consultations and assessments, requiring the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission and relevant provinces (cities) to strengthen monitoring, forecasting, and early warning, ensure flood control scheduling of key reservoirs such as the Three Gorges, and carry out dike inspections and defense work to ensure flood control safety.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en San Juan de 2014, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The floods in San Juan in 2014 were an extreme weather event that affected the south and east of the province of San Juan (Argentina) over several days in February 2014. It intensely affected the departments of Pocito, 25 de Mayo, and Valle Fértil. It also impacted Caucete, 9 de Julio, Santa Lucía, Rawson, Angaco, Chimbas, Zonda, 9 de Julio, Ullum, San Martín, and Sarmiento. During the event, rainfall reached a historic record for the province (where the annual average is 100 mm), recording 137.6 mm, surpassing the annual average. According to the Ministry of Human Development of the Government of the Province of San Juan, the number of evacuated people was 3,000.

One of the most affected areas was Pocito, where there were evacuated people and collapsed houses; another affected area was 25 de Mayo, in the localities of Casuarinas, Tupelí, and La Chimbera. Likewise, in Valle Fértil, it caused the overflow of a series of temporary rivers such as Las Tumanas and Del Valle, obstructing circulation on provincial route No. 510, where the localities of Usno, Astica, La Majadita, and Los Valencianos were heavily affected. Other affected areas were Caucete, where 350 people were evacuated; in Rawson, where there were 310 affected people; in Santa Lucía, with 200 affected people; in Angaco, with 150 affected; and Chimbas, with 17 flooded. Other affected departments were: Zonda, where 60 people were evacuated; 9 de Julio, where the number reached 56; Ullum, where 50 were evacuated; San Martín, where the number reached 25; and Sarmiento, where 20 evacuees were recorded.

Article_Name: Inundación en Santa Fe de 2007, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Santa Fe in 2007 was a meteorological event that occurred in March of that year, affecting the city of Santa Fe and surrounding areas due to heavy rainfall in the Argentine coastal region. A total of 437 millimeters of rain fell from March 26 to April 4, resulting in 26,000 evacuees.

The city of Santa Fe is located in an interfluvial zone with the Salado River to the west and the Paraná River system to the east, and features a set of streams, creeks, lagoons, and wetlands that represent 70% of the municipal district, framed in a floodplain. The rise of these has caused floods such as the one in 1983 due to the Paraná and the one in 2003 due to the Salado. On the other hand, the climate in Santa Fe is temperate without a dry season, according to the Köppen climate classification, with annual rainfall between 800 and 1100 mm, approximately half of which occurs between February and May. These terrestrial and climatic characteristics, along with the occupation of flood-prone lands, result in the continuous risk and water vulnerability experienced in the city.

Given the problems faced with the water situation, the government has built a series of defenses to prevent floods and inundations. The first and most primitive of these is the defense embankment or lateral dike, an artificial earth barrier located on riverbanks, separating rivers from flood-prone areas. To prevent water accumulation, as it cannot flow back into the rivers due to the embankments, a set of river defense structures was implemented, forming drainage works consisting of storm drains, pipes, and rainwater drains. This system channels water to reservoirs, areas adjacent to the embankments, which are depressed zones whose main function is to temporarily store water to later be emptied into nearby natural water currents. This emptying occurs in two ways: by gravity and by pumping. Gravity emptying is achieved through gates in the embankments that connect the reservoirs at their lowest point with a higher point in a water current. On the other hand, the pumping system operates through plants equipped with motor pumps capable of expelling water outside the defenses. By 2007, there were four pumping stations, known as pump houses, in operation, with two more lacking electrical connections. Pump house no. 1 was operating at 65% of its capacity, with two of the five pumps not working; no. 3 was operating at 65%, and no. 4 at 80%. In pump house no. 2, on March 14, an explosion occurred in one of the two pumps, which, at the time of the flood's onset, had not yet been repaired. By then, 27 of the 45 available pumps were not functioning, representing 60% of the pumping system.

On April 20, 2005, the Justicialist mayor Martín Balbarrey, elected in 2003, presented the Contingency Plan for the city, detailing all mechanisms to prevent crisis situations like the 2003 flood, with the aim of ensuring that every resident knew how to act in an emergency. The plan was prepared by official organizations and NGOs, along with neighborhood associations and specialists on the subject, and was led by Venezuelan Pedro Zuccarini, a disaster specialist who had been assisting the city since the 2003 flood on behalf of the German Red Cross. The plan established action protocols for organizations and institutions, the dissemination of necessary knowledge among the population to know how to react, and the creation of the Risk Action Office, prepared to act before, during, and after a disaster. A year later, on March 20, 2006, Balbarrey ordered the creation of the Risk Management Subsecretariat, under the Secretariat of Water Resources, appointing Pedro Zuccarini as its head. In June 2006, Proyecto Santa Fe, a study center led by then-national Radical deputy Hugo Storero, conducted a survey of 360 people and 56 institutions in twelve neighborhoods in the west, the area most affected by the 2003 flood. The results showed that most people would not know what to do in the event of a new flood, being unaware of the new Contingency Plan and the location of evacuation centers, although Zuccarini later denied the survey, claiming that "two out of five Santa Fe residents" knew the plan and were prepared. Another finding of the survey was that a majority of institutions did not believe another flood was possible. Zuccarini traveled to his home country, Venezuela, in December 2006, initially for personal reasons and later, according to Balbarrey, to present the projects implemented in Santa Fe to other parts of the world. By February 1, 2007, he had not returned, leading to his suspension without pay, and he was ultimately removed from his position on February 21. The nine-person team of the subsecretariat continued working, divided into two groups, one in charge of fieldwork and the other of logistics. This occurred in the context of the Paraná River's rise in February 2007, which affected the residents of Vuelta del Paraguayo.

Between March 26 and April 4, the Santa Fe departments of Belgrano, Caseros, Castellanos, Constitución, Garay, Iriondo, La Capital, Las Colonias, Rosario, San Jerónimo, San Lorenzo, and San Martín; and the Entre Ríos departments of Islas del Ibicuy, Gualeguay, Gualeguaychú, and Paraná. During those days, the total rainfall was 437 mm. On March 30, 15,000 residents from the western neighborhoods of San Pantaleón, Barranquitas, Villa del Parque, San Lorenzo, Chalet, and Santa Rosa de Lima left their homes for temporary shelter centers, following Mayor Balbarrey's declaration of a red alert and preventive evacuation of the area, as it was the most affected. Although the rain had decreased, the connection between water reservoirs caused an increase in other areas of the city. The Santa Fe-Rosario highway and Route 11 were impassable. The Army, Gendarmerie, and Coast Guard were in the city to provide assistance with food supplies, relief, and security.

According to Mayor Balbarrey, the causes were the large amount of rain, which exceeded all prior precautions; and the lack of maintenance and looting of the extractor pumps installed in the western area. The proliferation of settlements in flood-prone areas, the lack of maintenance of reservoirs, and the pump system.

Article_Name: Inundaciones del río Murray en 1956, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods of the Murray River in 1956

Whole_Text.content: Most of Australia has a very dry climate, and the central and southwestern parts of the island-continent make up the Great Australian Desert, one of the largest in the world (about 2.5 million km²). Only the northern part of the island-continent, which is already in the intertropical zone, as well as the southeastern mountains (Australian Alps), have a somewhat wetter climate. The Murray River, in turn, has an irregular flow regime and relatively low water volume, which is due to its long course through arid climate regions. Thus, although the Murray River with its tributaries (Darling, Murrumbidgee, and others) constitutes the largest river system in Australia, with more than one million km², its economic benefits for agriculture, industry, and potable water supply are not well developed, and there are possibilities to increase them through comprehensive basin planning. The Murray is a river that experiences strong floods and long periods of low water levels, so more multipurpose dams (hydroelectric, irrigation, flood control, and others) need to be built, infrastructure works need to be carried out to prevent damage in populations located mainly on the right bank of the river from the confluence with the Darling to the mouth, and areas with insufficient drainage (which in Australia are called billabongs and correspond in Spanish to terms such as abandoned meanders, oxbow lakes, marshes, or sporadically flooded areas, etc.) need to be channeled.

Whole_Text.header: Asymmetry of the Murray River basin
Whole_Text.content: When discussing the floods in the Australian Murray River basin, it should be noted that, as it is located in the southern hemisphere, any moving body, such as river water, tends to veer to the right, that is, opposite to the northern hemisphere. However, this deviation is not real but apparent, as it is not the river water that veers to the right but the Earth's surface that rotates from right to left (east to west), that is, counterclockwise. This means that, in a moving body with a constant direction (such as the Foucault pendulum), the apparent deviation would occur from left to right, or in other words, clockwise, for the simple reason that the pendulum's base, that is, the Earth's surface, rotates in the opposite direction (counterclockwise). This is why almost all the cities affected by the 1956 floods in the Murray basin were located on the river's right bank. Among the cities flooded on that occasion, we can mention, including their location on Google Maps: Colignan, Iraak, which no longer exists and was replaced by a lake that is now almost dried up, Mannum, Murray Bridge, Mildura, Nangiloc, whose name is written backward compared to Colignan, Red Cliffs, Renmark, Wentworth, and others. All the mentioned towns are situated on the right bank of the Murray River (except for a couple of cases where the town is divided in two by the river itself, as in Murray Bridge, although this is an exception that proves the rule because the force of the flood affected the part of the city on the right bank). The case of Iraak, which is somewhat separated from the Murray River and is now almost uninhabited, is due to the fact that it was originally a military camp during World War II (it also held prisoners), and during the 1956 floods, it was flooded, creating a lake that still exists: on one hand, the location of the place was precarious and risky and was only justified by its temporary use as a military zone. On the other hand, the floods of that year highlighted the risk of that location and worsened the initial problem: it was probably easier to dismantle the camp and relocate than to carry out infrastructure works to minimize or eliminate the risks of that location. The Google Earth program is very useful for assessing the flood risk of any location in Australia (or anywhere) since by moving the cursor over the satellite image, we automatically get the elevation in meters above sea level of any point, which can indicate the frequency of a situation where a river's natural levees are at a higher elevation than the surrounding plain, which is precisely why it is called a floodplain. In the specific case of Wentworth, which is located on the right bank of the Darling River at its confluence with the Murray, the main reason for the flooding was not directly due to the rise of this river but because this rise dammed the Darling's waters upstream of the confluence, overflowing to the north of the town, which was almost completely flooded for some time. In a desert or semi-desert climate, most rivers are allochthonous and can experience massive floods due to irregular rainfall, which can be very scarce for years but also very intense and disastrous on some sporadic occasions, exacerbated by the fact that the large amount of sediment carried by the river's waters (due to the sparse vegetation cover in a dry climate) tends to raise the riverbed and natural levees, especially the left one, in the case of the Murray River because we are in the southern hemisphere. This is why most floods caused by the river's overflow occurred on its right bank.

Whole_Text.header: The anomalous meteorology in the south and southeast of Australia in 1956
Whole_Text.content: Australia constitutes an isolated continent or, conversely, an island of continental scale. It is crossed by the Tropic of Capricorn in the northern part of the country, which gives this area an intertropical climate (savanna, rainforest in some places, and especially a dry subtropical climate). Most of the territory has a desert or semi-desert climate (Australia's deserts cover more than 2 million km²), and oceanic influences are very powerful, giving rise to tropical and extratropical storms, often very intense. In the specific case of Australia, the relatively dry climate makes it irregular, with years and even decades of very scarce rainfall and brief periods (weeks or months) of extraordinarily intense rains. In 1956, a rainy period lasting just over three months was recorded, leading to a massive flood that reached its highest point in Morgan, South Australia, at 12.3 meters, and these floods were felt up to 100 km away from the riverbanks. In the specific case of Morgan, its location on the right bank of the river (similar to the previously mentioned towns) is compounded by being situated on a 90° meander of the Murray River to the left, which concentrated the effects of the flood due to the natural right levee being lower than the left one in the southern hemisphere, so the centrifugal force of the river's flow in the bend was exerted towards the location of this town. This location can be seen on Google Maps: Morgan, South Australia.

Article_Name: Inundación de la Ciudad de México en 1629, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flooding of Mexico City in 1629 was an event that occurred starting on September 21 of that year, caused by heavy rain that lasted approximately 40 hours and resulted in the total flooding of the city. The water level reached a little over two meters, and the city remained flooded for five years, from September 1629 to 1634. Of the 20,000 Spanish families living in the city at that time, only 400 remained. The viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio, 3rd Marquess of Cerralbo, implemented several measures not only to alleviate the situation but also to prevent more people from leaving the city.

Tenochtitlan was founded in the lowest part of the Valley of Mexico, which is why its geographical location has always been the main cause of its vulnerability. Facing recurrent floods, the Mexica developed systems to control rising waters, such as retaining walls and aqueducts. With the implemented systems, they were able not only to supply themselves with clean water for consumption but also to prevent flooding. The Spanish, despite being aware of the existing soil subsidence problems in Tenochtitlan, decided to establish the capital of New Spain there for political reasons. In addition to the geographical location, there were other changes that resulted in the rise of water levels: environmental changes, deforestation, and the expansion of crops that led to soil erosion. All of this contributed to the city flooding on several occasions.

After these events, the construction of the Nochistongo Cut was approved to remove water from the city. The tunnel would have a length of 6,600 meters, a width of 3.50 meters, and a height of 4.50 meters.

When the rain began, Enrico Martínez advised Viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio to close the outlet of the Huehuetoca drainage, which was under construction, to prevent it from being destroyed. When the viceroy realized that this was only preventing the water from flowing out, he ordered the drainage to be uncovered, but it was too late.  
The city was submerged, many houses collapsed, others were flooded, and their inhabitants could only stay on the second floor. The unsanitary conditions, scarcity, and disease that followed the flood caused the death of approximately 30,000 people in the following years. The flood also caused many people to emigrate from the city, mostly settling in the city of Puebla. The viceroy wanted to prevent more people from leaving and took several measures to provide people with confidence and reassurance that the situation would improve.

Whole_Text.header: Measures of the Marquis of Cerralbo
Whole_Text.content:
The viceroy convened a council to decide what measures would be taken. It was decided to request a loan of 6,000 pesos, which would be used to buy and distribute food daily in the most affected neighborhoods. Food would also be sold to people who could afford it but had no means of transportation. Wooden bridges were built to make it possible to cross from one building to another. Canoes were also used for transportation within the city. To prevent more houses from collapsing, it was ordered that each homeowner build a type of wall attached to their house to prevent the foundations from weakening.

The measures taken to alleviate the situation were not enough; it was also necessary to remove the water from the city. To this end, the viceroy ordered the continuation of the construction of the Huehuetoca drainage system, which, after being opened, was damaged by the water.

There was a belief that the heavy rains were a punishment for the city's sins. It was accepted that masses could be held on rooftops or balconies so that people could listen to them from their homes. On an unprecedented occasion, on September 24, Archbishop Francisco Manso y Zúñiga allowed the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe to be taken by canoe from her Basilica to the city center. Given the situation and the lack of a short-term solution, the viceroy proposed to the city council the option of relocating the capital to another city. However, the city council responded that it would cost more money to move the capital than to rebuild it. It was decided that the only viable solution would be to find an effective drainage method. In 1634, the Carmelite friar and architect Andrés de San Miguel, commissioned by the viceroy, corrected the drainage channel of Mexico City, which had been built by Enrico Martínez, allowing the water to flow out of the city and enabling its reconstruction.

Article_Name: Inundación de la mina Delia II, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flooding of the Delia II mine
Whole_Text.content: The flooding of the Delia II mine occurred in the early hours of June 9, 2017, in the mine owned by the mining company "Cerro Bayo" and left two miners trapped in the tunnels. A collapse caused the waters of Laguna Verde (Aysén), in the commune of Chile Chico, to flood the mine's galleries. At the time of the flooding, which occurred in the early morning, miners Jorge Sánchez Martínez and Enrique Ojeda González were working on level 55. On the surface, outside the mine, it was noticed that the fans responsible for injecting fresh air into the shaft had stopped working, and an alarm sounded for only 10 seconds. At five in the morning, a supervisor entered the mine and discovered the tragedy: the mine had been flooded. The location of the workers at the time of the accident is unknown, but it is presumed that they headed to a shelter on level 203, which was attempted to be reached in a second drilling attempt, as the first one failed. Simultaneously, rescue teams tried to contain the flooding using dikes. The miners' unions proposed bringing in robots and divers to cross the flooded areas and search for the miners in the galleries. After 18 days of searching, on Tuesday, June 27, 2017, the Cerro Bayo company officially confirmed the death of the miners.

Article_Name: Inundación de México de 1446, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The great flood of Mexico-Tenochtitlán in 1446 caused mortality and severe damage to the chinampa system in the city of Mexico-Tenochtitlán during the reign of Moctezuma I. After the flood, there was scarcity and hunger. The situation did not normalize until the year 1455.

Tenochtitlán was located in the lower part of the Valley of Mexico, on an islet in the ancient Lake Texcoco. Such a geographical location made it vulnerable to flooding despite the adaptation of its inhabitants to their natural environment, reflected in the ingenious chinampa system. By 1382, a partial flood had already been recorded, causing serious damage to the city founded in 1325. At the time of the flood, the Mexica, under the command of Moctezuma I, had triumphed in the Chalco war, an event that consolidated their dominance in the Anáhuac. In the same year as the flood, shortly before, a locust (grasshopper) plague had occurred, affecting the corn harvest.

According to the chronicles, heavy rains and hail fell in the year seven, ácatl (1446). The water level rose to the branches of the trees, causing numerous deaths. All the streets of the city were flooded, several houses were destroyed, and people were forced to transport themselves exclusively in canoes. Emperor Moctezuma I, deeply distressed, sought advice from Nezahualcóyotl, lord of Texcoco, who advised him to build a causeway, from what is now La Villa to Iztapalapa, as a dike to protect the city from future floods. The idea was accepted and executed with the labor of the peoples of Azcapotzalco, Coyoacán, Tlacópan, Xochimilco, Iztapalapa, Culhuacán, and Tenayócan. Even the main nobles of Tenochtitlán participated in the work. In the end, the dike measured nine miles long by eleven fathoms wide. With these works, the flooding was partially mitigated.

The disaster of the flood was followed by famine, as in the next two years the corn harvest was very scarce. In the year 1450, the harvest was poor due to a series of droughts and hailstorms, so by 1452 the need of the peoples of Anáhuac was "so great" that the upper classes opened their granaries for the benefit of their vassals. Despite this, the people's diet was sustained by consuming waterfowl, marsh herbs, roots, insects, and fish from the same lake. The year of greatest scarcity and hunger was 1454. As a result of the famine, many inhabitants left the region, some died in the fields, and others sought refuge in regions like Totonacapan (present-day Sierra Norte de Puebla) never to return. Ixtlilxóchitl states that the desperation was so great that some sold their children to the inhabitants of Totonacapan in exchange for corn. Finally, in 1455, there were abundant rains and a good harvest that ended the famine.

Whole_Text.header: Interpretation and political consequences of the flood
Whole_Text.content: It was believed that the gods were upset because sacrifices were not being made to them, and for this reason, the sacred or flower wars were established. This meant that the peoples of the region had to periodically go to battle. This event continued the series of conquests by Moctezuma I and not only increased the fame and political influence of Tenochtitlán but also enriched it and made it the most populated city in the region.

Article_Name: Riada de Tenerife de 2010, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The so-called Tenerife Flood of 2010 took place on February 1 of that year (the eve of the Feast of the Virgin of Candelaria), mainly affecting the metropolitan area of Santa Cruz de Tenerife (Canary Islands, Spain). Unlike the previous major flood experienced in Tenerife, namely the flood of 2002, the 2010 flood was not limited to the city of Santa Cruz de Tenerife and its immediate surrounding areas but rather the powerful Atlantic storm affected practically all of the Canary Islands, although with much greater impact in Santa Cruz de Tenerife. Also, and unlike what happened in 2002, the 2010 flood did not result in any fatalities.

During the storm, it is estimated that 187 liters per square meter fell in Santa Cruz de Tenerife, in nearby areas such as San Cristóbal de La Laguna 270 liters in 24 hours, and in Anaga 253 in 12 hours. The storm caused a large number of city residents to be evacuated while streets, squares, and tunnels were flooded. The resulting mud rendered roads and commercial establishments inoperative, paralyzing part of the city's economic activity. The rain and wind storm collapsed the main roads and highways and kept the entire archipelago on orange alert. Just days later, on February 18, another storm, although of lesser intensity, caused a blackout that affected the entire island of Tenerife. A chain failure of the electrical groups in the island's two power plants occurred, resulting in what is technically known as an energy zero, that is, a total blackout due to the collapse of the supply. Five hours after the blackout, the power supply began to recover. This blackout was harshly criticized in the political arena, as it was considered unacceptable for a total blackout to occur on an island with more than 900,000 inhabitants.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en Centroamérica de 2011, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The floods in Central America in 2011 affected the territories of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama. They were caused by low-pressure systems that lasted more than a week, and the impact of the meteorological phenomenon caused damage to local infrastructure, more than one hundred deaths, and at least 800,000 affected people. The intensity of the events has been attributed to climate change by experts on the subject.

The rains in Costa Rica began approximately on October 7, and in the following days, a preliminary amount of 17 cantons in the Pacific coast and Central Valley were reported to be affected by landslides and floods. On October 10, the National Emergency Commission (CNE) declared a green alert, based on the presence of a low-pressure system near the country that was producing "intense rainfall with accumulations between 150 to 200 mm in 254 hours." By the 19th and 20th, the National Emergency Commission (CNE) estimated 12,000 affected people, 995 evacuated, four dead, and two missing, "as a consequence of the climatic contingency, which exceeded the monthly average rainfall." Meanwhile, the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock estimated losses in pastures (20,000 hectares destroyed) and the sugarcane sector (4,300 hectares), rice (3,200 hectares), and tomatoes. The storm, which was classified as one of the longest in the history of the United States, broke the record for the most damaging storm in terms of road infrastructure, after reporting damage to more than 1,590 kilometers of roads throughout the country, as well as 4,300 hectares of sugarcane, 3,200 hectares of rice, and 20,000 hectares of pasture flooded after the storm.

The rains began in El Salvador on October 10, and in the following ten days, a historic record of 1,504 millimeters of water accumulated, surpassing the levels of Hurricane Mitch in 1998. Additionally, an estimated 10% of the territory was affected by the floods, along with damage to agriculture, destruction of bridges and roads caused by river overflows and landslides. According to a report from the National Territorial Studies Service on October 17, "the large amount of precipitation was caused by a Low Pressure system that was later classified as Tropical Depression 12E, preceded by a broad depression field formed in Central America." President Mauricio Funes declared a state of emergency throughout the territory on October 14. Likewise, in a speech delivered on the 19th of the same month, he stated: Meanwhile, the Legislative Assembly declared a state of public calamity and disaster on the 17th. In a report from the General Directorate of Civil Protection on October 20, it was revealed that a total of 34 people had lost their lives, four bridges had collapsed, 879 landslides occurred on various roads in the country, and an estimated 1 million Salvadorans were "more closely impacted." On October 21, it was reported that a total of 181 municipalities in the country were affected. Data from the Ministry of Agriculture authorities revealed "the loss of 987,890 quintals of corn, 369,835 quintals of beans, 228,502 quintals of sorghum, and 92,252 quintals of rice."

Tropical Depression 12E struck Guatemala starting on October 11, and after 14 hours of uninterrupted rain, 42 road sections were reported damaged by landslides, in addition to overflowing rivers and floods. About 14 of the country's 22 departments were affected. On October 17, President Álvaro Colom declared a state of public calamity. In a speech, the president stated: By October 20, the National Coordinator for Disaster Reduction reported that the rains had resulted in 38 deaths, 5 missing persons, and 524,480 affected individuals. Meanwhile, the Guatemalan Chamber of Agriculture detailed that the country's agricultural income could "decrease... by up to about 37.5 million dollars." Additionally, the Ministry of Agriculture asserted that according to its "partial calculations," the damage caused by the rains to agricultural crops would reach 43 million quetzals (about 5.3 million dollars).

In the southern region of Honduras, the rains began on October 11, causing the overflow of the Choluteca River, which affected the capital city of the department with the same name. Another department where damages were reported was Valle, as well as Texiguat, in El Paraíso. The floods affected various road sections in the area. President Porfirio Lobo declared an emergency in the southern region of the country on October 16, part of his speech was: By October 20, the Permanent Contingency Commission (COPECO) issued a report stating a total of 18 deaths, 59,663 people affected, 549 displaced, 52 damaged roads, and 11 destroyed bridges, among other calamities caused by the conditions of the "intertropical convergence zone." Additionally, around 9,000 manzanas of crops were reported lost. The devastation reached the departments of Valle, Choluteca, Francisco Morazán, El Paraíso, Lempira, and Intibucá.

Also in Nicaragua, rains were reported starting October 10, and within the first 12 hours, river overflows and damage to the road network in the departments of Chinandega and León were recorded; as well as in Managua and Masaya, an undetermined number of homes ended up flooded. In response to the emergency, the Nicaraguan government, led by President Daniel Ortega, declared a state of calamity and disaster across the entire national territory on October 17. It was also announced that 133,858 people had been affected throughout the country, mainly in Managua, Carazo, Granada, Chinandega, León, Madriz, and Estelí, where "15,000 families were isolated due to road cuts and floods." By the 19th, official data revealed figures of "12 dead, one missing, and 150,000 people affected, as well as 75,000 isolated and 10,300 sheltered in 104 temporary shelters," as a result of the relentless rains.

In Panama, on October 11, around 900 people were evacuated following the overflow of the Chiriquí Viejo River and the rupture of a natural dam—formed by landslides that blocked the waters of the Palo Blanco River—in the localities of Progreso, La Esperanza, and Baco in the Barú district. President Ricardo Martinelli requested that people in the risk zone cooperate with the evacuation, which saved many lives in Chiriquí. According to government data, 450 people were relocated to shelters: 250 of them in a gymnasium and 150 in a high school located in Puerto Armuelles, while the rest took refuge in the homes of relatives and/or friends.

The Salvadoran Foreign Minister Hugo Martínez announced the call for a meeting between the presidents of the so-called "Northern Triangle," made up of Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, in the city of San Salvador. Additionally, an invitation was extended to "other leaders of the member countries of the Central American Integration System (SICA), which includes Belize, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Panama," all "with the purpose of presenting a request for aid to the international community." On the other hand, it was intended that each country present a report on the damages caused by the storm and the resources required to "undertake reconstruction." The meeting, held on October 25 and hosted by President Mauricio Funes, was attended by the leaders Álvaro Colom, Laura Chinchilla, and Porfirio Lobo, along with the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos and the ambassadors of Belize, Panama, and the Dominican Republic.
