Article_Name: Inundaciones en la región litoral del Ecuador de 2008, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods in the coastal region of Ecuador in 2008
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the coastal region of Ecuador were a large-scale natural disaster that occurred in early January 2008, affecting the entire coastal region of Ecuador, in the provinces of Guayas, Santa Elena, El Oro, Manabí, Los Ríos, and Esmeraldas.

The winter season on the Ecuadorian coast caused great damage to the rural population of the region, disproportionately suffering the consequences of the disaster, being vulnerable to risks that affected health, housing, agriculture, education, goods, and services. The increase in rain, temperature, and air humidity as a result of global warming caused a greater impact on various socioeconomic sectors. The lack of early warning mechanisms and the poor management of dikes and dams, for various reasons, are considered factors that have increased the magnitude of the disaster.

Humidity unleashed hurricane-force winds in the Province of Guayas, in Milagro, Naranjito, Santa Lucía, and El Empalme. The hurricane-force winds, which were accompanied by heavy rains and thunderstorms, are due to climate change and deforestation.

34 fatalities have been reported due to floods, river overflows, landslides, etc. So far, 12,000 people have been evacuated to 281 shelters. Around 75,000 productive hectares have been affected, 55,000 lost, and $63 million in agricultural and livestock losses. Landslides buried vehicles and roads. A torrent of stones, rocks, and mud fell on the night of March 8 on the Portoviejo-Quevedo road, in the San Plácido sector, crushing three vehicles: a bus from the Reales Tamarindos cooperative, a car, and a truck.

The National Government of the Republic of Ecuador instructed the Ministry of the Coast to work with all Regional Subsecretariats on a contingency plan to provide aid and rescue to those affected in the impacted areas. This work was carried out in coordination with the three branches of the Armed Forces of Ecuador, the National Police, Civil Defense, and with the collaboration of international aid organizations. Eight working groups were established to outline and set the parameters for assistance.

Article_Name: Inundación de Formosa en 1983, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Formosa in 1983 occurred on May 31 of that same year, when the river reached its peak and about 60,000 people were evacuated.

Since the founding of the City in 1879, new settlements had to be established in lower areas, closer to the coast, closer to the river, as if challenging its territory, even though knowing this represented an indefinite risk. Thus, a significant percentage of the urban area developed on the periphery of the original settlement, creating populous and densely populated neighborhoods. After several decades, the inhabitants and the authorities believed they were completely safe, thinking that nothing and no one could devastate the already established urban area. They began "reclaiming" land from the river by partially filling in coastal areas, altering the ecosystem, destroying forests, degrading the soil, and building houses and factories in risk-prone zones. Large projects were also planned, such as a Coastal Avenue. However, these were nothing more than simple political promises. At that time, the floods of the Paraguay River were scarce, weak, and manageable. The inhabitants knew how far the water would reach during each event. But during the 1960s and 1970s, the floods became characterized by greater frequency, longer duration, and increasingly significant hydrometric readings. By 1979, with a maximum height of 8.32 meters, the Paraguay River caused significant losses and thousands of evacuations, serving as a sort of warning of what was to come. After these inconveniences, settlements near the riverbanks were reestablished, believing it would not happen again. By July 1982, a new river flood raised the waters to 8.68 meters, surpassing the 1979 mark, causing millions of pesos in losses and affecting more than 18,000 people, marking the beginning of what would become the largest flood of the century recorded in the Argentine littoral. From then on, the water remained stagnant, rising and falling but always within normal parameters.

Due to the low temperatures and heavy rains in the Paraná River basins, by the end of April 1983, the Paraguay River levels had already reached 8.90 meters in height at the Formosa port. The provinces of Santa Fe, Misiones, Corrientes, and Chaco had been in a state of emergency for almost a month, and even the Barranqueras port had disappeared under the ever-rising waters. As the situation became uncontrollable, Formosa was declared in a state of emergency; the Paraguay River had surpassed 9 meters, and the disaster began to worsen, first in the island and riverside areas, and then in the peripheral neighborhoods of the capital and nearby towns, threateningly surrounding populated centers without defenses or adequate resources to face such an overflow. Then, everything turned to indignation and sadness. The waters had already devastated towns like Clorinda and Herradura, cut off roads and highways, and were still advancing. In both the capital and Clorinda, the desperate construction of coastal defense works began, surrounding the urban core, built on the highest perimeters with compacted soil brought in by trucks operating tirelessly and piled up by road machinery, forming a containment barrier. This grueling work involved the movement of 340 trucks and 119 heavy equipment units between the two cities, the transport of over 1,000,000 cubic meters of soil, and the tireless solidarity of thousands of anonymous hands who day and night reinforced the embankments with sandbags, drove stakes, and fought to save what belonged to everyone. But the river did not stop rising; it kept advancing and surpassed the 10-meter mark with no intention of stopping. At the local port, activity was relentless; thousands of evacuated families with the few belongings they could rescue were assisted by every available vessel, such as the sand dredger Capri VI, which made tireless trips transporting populations from nearby areas like Alberdi in Paraguay and the most affected island sectors, or the Navy ship 'Piloto Alsina,' which served as shelter and assistance for hundreds of affected families. On May 31, 1983, the river reached its maximum level: 10.73 meters, plunging the city of Formosa into the worst chaos: schools turned into evacuation centers, classes suspended, basic services provided inefficiently, supermarkets out of stock, businesses closing, producers losing everything, and more than 10,000 Formosans deciding to leave a province that suddenly frightened them. But many stayed; they helped distribute food, clothing, and medicine among the more than 75 evacuation centers scattered throughout the city, reinforced the hope in the containment barriers, collaborated with Civil Defense, the Red Cross, the Coast Guard, the Air Force, the Army, and the Gendarmerie in whatever was necessary, trying to save what belonged to them and fighting to the end in a sort of personal battle to avenge the misfortune of nearly 70,000 people affected by the waters of a river that showed no mercy, that was relentless, and that exacted a heavy toll for human recklessness. By mid-June, the water began its steady retreat; it had calmed down and finally gave up. It left behind desolation, sadness, lost dreams, and for many, an inevitable new beginning; it also left in memory the recollection of the solidarity of a people who decided not to give up and fought to save their belongings and their dignity.
The floods of 1983 exceeded the average height of the river by 6.13 meters.

Article_Name: Inundación de León de los Aldama de 1926, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood of León de los Aldama in 1926
Whole_Text.content:
Floods have been one of the scourges that have most frequently afflicted the city of León de los Aldama since its founding in 1576. Partly caused by nature, the negligence of citizens and authorities has also played an important role. León was founded and has grown on an almost flat terrain that hardly allows for the rapid drainage of water that comes from higher areas after heavy rains. This excess water, which the rivers crossing the city cannot drain, spills over the urban area and causes catastrophic floods, large and with strong currents. In the early hours of June 23, 1926, much of the population was sleeping peacefully when they were awakened by street cries and police whistles warning of the danger looming over the city: the Río de Los Gómez was overflowing on 5 de Mayo Street! At dawn, the El Muerto stream also began to spill over the town of El Coecillo, collapsing fragile adobe houses and killing their occupants. To make matters worse, at nine in the morning, a second, more violent current followed, caused by the destruction of the dam wall of the Hacienda de Arriba.

The bells of the temples rang furiously, warning people to flee, but upon leaving their homes, they found that the streets had turned into rushing torrents that inexorably rose in level, sweeping away everything in their path. The current flowed past the facades, carrying furniture, mattresses, clothes, and a few human and animal corpses in its wake. With difficulty, people began to cross the streets, clinging to doors, window bars, or lampposts, carrying their youngest children and some of their most precious belongings on their backs.

Most tried to reach high places like Bellavista and the hills of La Soledad or El Santuario, while others found refuge in the Teatro Doblado, the Seminary, the Municipal Palace, the Reforma Bullring, and even the Modelo School, Círculo Leonés Mutualista, and private homes.

The people of León had almost no resources and managed however they could to eat and survive. A thousand homes and buildings collapsed, material losses were estimated at twelve million pesos, and the dead—according to official figures—were more than eighty. On June 29, the municipal president Guadalupe Núñez and several residents created the "Aid Committee," which was responsible for organizing relief activities and managing the funds that were being collected. This committee was chaired by Don Enrique Aranda. The reconstruction of the city took place during difficult times, as the Mexican Revolution had just ended, but what would become the Cristero War was already brewing. Many families emigrated, and those who stayed had to face the misery caused by the catastrophe. Even today, León is crossed by numerous rivers, streams, and canals, so floods remain a daily occurrence: We must not forget that water always finds and follows its path.

Article_Name: Riada de 1907, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1907, popularly known as the "great flood," was a catastrophic inundation that took place during the early hours of Tuesday, September 24, 1907, in the Spanish city of Málaga.

The one in September 1907 was the fourth in a series of floods that occurred at the beginning of the century: in 1901, on November 4, 1902, and on September 4, 1905. Previously, there is evidence of other severe floods that occurred in 1661, 1764, and 1786, among others. With the distribution of Malaga's lands carried out after the Christian conquest of Málaga, the forests of the Montes de Málaga began to be cut down, and the lands were cleared for vine cultivation, leaving the city, located at the end of a steep valley at the mouth of the Guadalmedina, defenseless against storms. The situation worsened with the phylloxera plague that devastated the province in the last third of the 19th century and the consequent abandonment of the vineyards.

The flood occurred without any rain in the city, when an avalanche of water and mud from the Guadalmedina basin, where there had been heavy downpours, rushed into Málaga around one in the morning. The wall of water, mud, and sludge first knocked down the old La Aurora bridge, which obstructed the water's flow as it got stuck at the Santo Domingo bridge, until this one also gave way, repeating the situation at the Tetuán bridge, located downstream and the only one that withstood, as the next bridge, the railway bridge, was also destroyed. The sudden increase in the river's flow caused it to overflow, quickly flooding the neighborhoods of El Perchel and La Trinidad and many other low-lying areas of the city. During the catastrophe, twenty-one people drowned, and many others were injured. The waters reached up to five meters in height, and according to witnesses, there was so much mud and debris that it was possible to access some houses through the balconies. The material damages were estimated at around five and a half million pesetas of the time, and it took up to two months to completely clean the streets.

Alfonso XIII ordered that, with the utmost urgency, the necessary works be carried out to prevent the recurrence of floods in Málaga. In 1908, the Málaga-born engineer Manuel Jiménez Lombardo presented the project for the construction of the Agujero dam to the Hydraulic Division of Southern Spain. The dam would retain the waters of the large autumn floods of the Guadalmedina, storing approximately 4.5 cubic hectometers, which would gradually be released through a tunnel with a capacity of 360 m³ and drains of 60 m³/second. Likewise, given the scale of the catastrophe and also in gratitude for the behavior of the city of Málaga during the shipwreck of the frigate SMS Gneisenau, the German government gifted the city the Puente de los Alemanes (Bridge of the Germans), inaugurated in 1909. The Agujero dam, although efficient in its limited function, could not be the ultimate solution to the problem of floods, as hydrological studies of the basin showed that it did not fully guarantee the city's safety. After decades of discussions and debates between supporters of solutions based solely on hydraulic works—civil engineers—and supporters of hydrological-forestry restoration—forestry engineers—the reforestation of the river basin was undertaken, accompanied by the construction of sediment retention dikes. In 1919, José Almagro San Martín, a forestry engineer from the 7th Hydrological-Forestry Division, completed the drafting of the "Project for the Correction of the Guadalmedina Basin." Its execution began in 1929 with the arrival in the city of another forestry engineer, José Martínez Falero. Nearly 5,000 hectares on the left bank of the river were expropriated and reforested, and 30 hydraulic masonry dikes were built. Colonizing species such as Aleppo pine and stone pine were used, effectively fulfilling the protective and restorative objective for the basin's soils, forming the forest mass of the Montes de Málaga natural park. Years later, in 1983, 2.5 km downstream from El Agujero, the El Limonero reservoir was built with a capacity of 25 cubic hectometers, rendering the old El Agujero reservoir obsolete—today its gates and spillways are out of use, though operational, as the Limonero dam is located further downstream—and, together with the aforementioned reforestation measures, solved the severe floods that Málaga had historically faced. The last governmental initiative aimed at increasing the forested area of the Guadalmedina basin was carried out by the Málaga City Council in 2002, with the expropriation of nearly 400 hectares on the right bank, which were reforested in collaboration with the Ministry of the Environment.

Article_Name: Riada en la rambla Nogalte de 1973, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flood in the Nogalte ravine of 1973
Whole_Text.content: The flood of October 19, 1973, is considered one of the worst known floods that occurred on the Iberian Peninsula. Precipitation of around 250 ml was recorded. A maximum flow of 3000 m³/s was reached, and the water reached 15 meters in height in Puerto Lumbreras and 10 meters in Lorca. The significant load of solid materials carried (30% of the flow) increased the destructive capacity of the waters as they passed through Puerto Lumbreras, causing 89 deaths and numerous damages in the town, to which must be added 13 fatalities in Lorca (also in Murcia), 10 in Zurgena, Vélez Rubio, and Macael (Almería), and more than 50 in La Rábita (Granada).

Most of the area drained by the Nogalte ravine is located within the isohyet of an average annual precipitation of 400 mm, with a marked decrease during the summer months. On some occasions, intense rainfall occurs over short periods of time, causing strong surface runoff that is increased by contributions from other ravines that flow into the Nogalte ravine. Historical records of such floods in the Nogalte ravine are kept in the Municipal Archive of Lorca: the "Deluge" flood in September 1568, the one on September 17, 1623, the one on October 15, 1651 "San Calixto," the one on June 28, 1877, the one on October 14, 1879 "Santa Teresa," preceded by the damaging, terrible, copious, and devastating flood of June 27, 1877. In the 20th century, another catastrophic flood occurred in 1948, known as the "ranchito" flood.

On October 17, 18, and 19, 1973, a large amount of rainfall occurred, primarily concentrated in the upper basin of the Guadalentín River, that is, the Vélez, Luchena rivers, and the Nogalte ravine. On October 19, 151.5 mm were recorded in Vélez Rubio and 95.6 mm in Puerto Lumbreras, with a maximum rainfall of 300 mm in less than two hours in the part of the Almería province within the Segura basin. With such intense rainfall, combined with the lack of vegetation cover, the main basins in the area overflowed. In the province of Almería, the main receiving basins recorded more than 600 million m³, and in some areas, the waters exceeded 15 meters in height. However, it was in the Region of Murcia where the flood was most severe. In Lorca, a flow rate of over 2,500 m³/s was recorded in the Guadalentín. In Puerto Lumbreras, the Nogalte ravine reached 1,974 m³/s, of which 814 m³/s were solid flow and 1,160 m³/s were liquid flow, with a specific flow of 14,200 l/s/km². The sediment accounted for 41.18% of the total flow, 70.02% of the liquid flow, a very high figure when similar basins typically accepted values of 40 to 50%.[2] Successive floods were caused by continuous blockages-unblockages and landslides of tons of soil upstream of the channel. Notably, in just two hours, 12 hm³ of water and 8,000 m² of solid material passed through this town, destroying everything in their path.[1]

In the province of Almería, 10 fatalities were reported in the towns of Zurgena, Vélez Rubio, and Macael. There were numerous material losses, both in infrastructure and housing, as well as in agriculture, with losses of trees, crops, and 8,000 farm animals. In the province of Granada, in the town of La Rábita, the bridge passing directly above the urban center became blocked. This created a dam that, upon breaking, released an enormous amount of water and tons of accumulated sediment, destroying dozens of houses and causing the death of more than fifty people. In Lorca, 13 people died, while in Puerto Lumbreras, which was the hardest hit, the total number rose to 89. The flood destroyed 3 km of the national road to Murcia, overflowing the bridge over the dry riverbed, which stands over 8 meters high. In a letter sent three days after the disaster by the Mayor to the Minister of Finance, it was reported that almost all municipal services had disappeared, such as the Market Square, the Municipal Slaughterhouse, the Potable Water Pumping Station, the Weighing Scale, or the Fountain, trough, and washhouse of Los Caños. In the rest of the region, the waters of the Guadalentín River, to which the Nogalte dry riverbed is a tributary, in turn flooded the Segura River, of which it is a tributary, affecting large depressions in Sangonera la Verde, much of the Murcia orchard, and the Vega Baja.

Article_Name: Riada de San Policarpo, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The San Policarpo Flood was a flood caused by the overflow of the Tormes River that affected numerous homes, religious temples, and infrastructures in the city of Salamanca (Spain). The flood occurred on January 26, 1626. This overflow of the Tormes caused nearly one and a half hundred deaths, affected more than one and a half thousand homes to varying degrees, and destroyed vital infrastructures for the proper functioning of the city. The rise managed to reach the level of the rear part of what is now the Convent of San Esteban and flooded a large part of the Salamanca suburb.

The year 1626 begins with abundant snow, followed by a period of intense rains that cause widespread flooding in the Duero basin, affected by the overflows of several of its tributaries. The Tormes River, being one of them, experiences an uncontrolled and sudden increase in flow that occurs within a short interval of less than five hours during the night of January 26-27 (the feast day of Saint Polycarp). This sudden flood causes numerous damages and deaths in the city’s plain, remaining in history as the so-called Night of Saint Polycarp. In the flood, 142 people who were caught off guard during the night lost their lives. The churches located in the river plain were seriously affected. The Roman bridge crossing the river suffered severe damage, requiring extensive restoration. Four arches on the side farthest from the city completely collapsed, leaving the city cut off on that side; in the following days, more arches collapsed until stopping at the central tower. The bridge was rebuilt starting in 1627, during the reign of Philip IV. The rains caused another flood in February of the same year but with lesser consequences.

Article_Name: Inundación en La Plata de 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The 2013 flood in La Plata was an event that affected the city of La Plata, the capital of the province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, and its surrounding areas between April 2 and 3, 2013, with a record of extraordinary rainfall, more recurrent in the region, accumulating over 400 mm in four hours. The rains caused severe flooding throughout the Buenos Aires Metropolitan Area, where the toll was 89 confirmed judicial deaths.

On April 2, 2013, the city of La Plata and its surroundings were affected by continuous rainfall. The National Meteorological Service reported that 181 mm fell between 6 PM and 9 PM, with an estimated value of up to 200 mm in other unmeasured areas; the cities of Ensenada and Berisso and the neighborhoods of Los Hornos, Villa Elvira, and Tolosa in La Plata were the most affected, along with the city center. The confirmed number of fatalities was 89. A total of 2,200 people were evacuated.

On March 30, a minimum pressure axis was observed west of the Pacific coast, which quickly evolved into a closed low-pressure center at mid-troposphere levels (known as a cold drop, DANA, or cut-off low). Starting April 1, this closed center moved very slowly from west to east over the center of the country. This low-pressure center created favorable conditions for widespread upward movements in the central-east of Argentina, a necessary condition for cloud formation. On April 2, the development of an incipient frontal wave located in the west of Buenos Aires province, combined with a 1023hPa anticyclone located southeast of Mar del Plata, generated intense and persistent northeast quadrant winds over the east of the province. This condition favored the entry of humid air into the region affected by heavy rainfall, evidenced by the sustained increase in water vapor content, which reached maximum values of between 40 and 45 mm in Ezeiza in the early hours of April 2. The emagrams obtained through a radiosonde showed a vertical wind profile from the northeast quadrant in a layer approximately 1500 m high, which extended to greater heights on April 1.

Whole_Text.header: Evolution of the event in the City of La Plata and surroundings
Whole_Text.content: The first areas of precipitation developed over the Río de la Plata and moved in a south-southwest direction. Around 4:00 PM HOA, a significant area of rain and storms entered the districts of Ensenada and Berisso, continuing along the eastern edge of the La Plata district. One of the cells also generated a tornado near the town of Ensenada. Between 5:00 PM and 5:10 PM HOA, an initial storm cell reached the city of La Plata, remaining in that area for approximately one hour. At the same time, successive images show that the storm cells did not exhibit significant movement, suggesting that they were continuously regenerating over the same area, thereby favoring the persistence of rainfall in that region. Although the area affected by the most intense precipitation (according to radar information) extended in a north-south strip from the boundary between Berisso and Ensenada towards the La Plata district, around 8:00 PM HOA, a fairly intense storm cell developed over the city of La Plata, remaining there for approximately two hours (until 10:00 PM HOA). Subsequently, the entire area of bad weather began to move eastward, towards the Río de la Plata.
The Faculty of Engineering of the National University of La Plata released a report on the causes and consequences of the catastrophe that occurred in La Plata on April 2, 2013.

The architect Roberto Livingston and the environmentalist Osvaldo Guerrica Echevarría identified design errors and climate change as the main causes of the floods. There is a theory that the Buenos Aires/La Plata Highway was, in part, a cause of the flooding, as it did not have the necessary number of bridges for proper water drainage, an issue that had been raised but not taken into account during its construction. This deficiency would have left the El Gato stream as the only drainage channel. Thus, the specific observed causes would be: In 2007, a report from the Department of Hydraulics of the Faculty of Engineering of the University of La Plata had identified drainage problems in the El Gato stream basin. It had also warned about the need to address the overflow of the reservoirs on Avenida 32, which, during heavy rains, expelled water instead of retaining it. A fundamental issue would be the disorganized demographic growth of real estate in La Plata over the last ten years, which led to the disappearance of large green spaces, historic buildings, and diagonals. It was estimated that more than 800,000 square meters were built between 2003 and 2008, while one million square meters were constructed in the two years prior to the flood. It was also considered that the 2009 Urban Planning Code of La Plata allowed for the construction of more towers in the central area, which may have exacerbated the flooding. Additionally, there is an investigation against the YPF refinery in Ensenada due to an accusation that claims the closure of a canal gate, carried out to combat a fire caused by the storm, was the main cause of the flooding. The report from the Department of Hydraulics of the Faculty of Engineering of the National University of La Plata states that the hydraulic infrastructure works were not prepared for the event, that the meteorological alert was not issued in time, and that the actions taken by public officials were late, insufficient, and chaotic. The Municipality of La Plata is responsible for the rainwater drainage conduits. Furthermore, the Municipal Emergency Committee has an Emergency Protocol for events like this that should have been activated.

The acting president at the time, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, stated that in the face of "inefficiency and ineffectiveness, those who end up suffering the most are the vulnerable, those who should have the most protection" and emphasized that "there are structural problems that have nothing to do with the storm" and announced an audit. The governor of the province of Buenos Aires, Daniel Scioli, said, "An unprecedented deluge in history." He declared an administrative and educational holiday.

The Secretary of National Security, Sergio Berni, and the Minister of Social Development, Alicia Kirchner, toured the affected areas and visited a donation center. The governor of the Province of Buenos Aires, Daniel Scioli, visited an evacuation center located in Tolosa (one of the most affected areas) and the San Martín Club, a site where aid for those affected by the flood had been concentrated. The head of the national executive branch arrived by helicopter and spoke with those affected by the storm in the Tolosa neighborhood: "I experienced it when I was a girl, I was 15 years old, my house flooded over there on 7th Street," she said, adding, "It was the time when the El Gato stream was not channeled, that's why I know, and I wanted to come because I know what it's like to have water up to here, inside your house." "Mom is without electricity and gas but doesn't want to leave the house because the water reached the door, she's afraid it will rain again and doesn't want to leave because there's a leak in the roof." The president was unaware that the El Gato stream was never channeled. The President visited parishes and schools and met with young volunteers, where, sitting with them on the floor, she learned about the mechanisms of aid for those affected. Subsequently, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner declared three days of national mourning through decree No. 341/13.

The floods caused a fire at the YPF refinery in Ensenada. In a statement, the company reported that "The emergency occurred in the midst of this climatic phenomenon, due to an extraordinary accumulation of rainwater and a power outage across the entire complex" around 8:00 PM on April 1, and that "After four in the morning, the personnel working on-site managed to extinguish the fire. Two fire brigades and specialized company personnel were involved. No injuries were reported during the containment efforts."

YPF implemented an emergency plan to ensure the normal supply of fuel to service stations. There were cross-accusations between the national government, the provincial government, and the municipal government regarding responsibilities, which triggered the discontent of those affected. The mayor of La Plata, Pablo Bruera, from the Social Progress Party (an internal faction of the Justicialist Party in La Plata), provoked the anger of residents by claiming on Twitter that he was touring the affected areas while he was on vacation at a beach in Brazil.
In the city of La Plata, 120,000 users were affected by power outages, 190,000 affected, more than 70,000 homes flooded, and economic losses estimated at 3.4 billion pesos.

Before the Justice, those responsible for the SMN explained that the radar that was supposed to monitor the approaching phenomenon in La Plata was broken. The main focus of the storm occurred between 4:00 PM and 7:00 PM that day. It was not until a year later that the Justice system managed to establish the number of fatalities caused by the tragedy. The death toll was 89, 70 percent of whom were over 65 years old. The investigation conducted by the Administrative Litigation Judge of La Plata, Luis Arias, opened the possibility that another 16 people may have died during the storm, although the number could not be conclusively proven. The aforementioned magistrate also ordered the adaptation of death registration procedures, the relocation of people living on the banks of the Del Gato and Maldonado streams, as well as the suspension of real estate developments, among other causes that generated unrest in political and business circles. The Administrative Litigation Judge of La Plata, Luis Arias, was later suspended and removed by a jury initiated during the government of María Eugenia Vidal. The magistrate received support from political, social, and human rights organizations. In fact, the Tolosa Flood Victims Assembly expressed its support for Arias for "promoting a thorough investigation into the number of deaths caused by the flood." Neither Governor Scioli nor Mayor Bruera (the latter with a disgraceful attempt to conceal his vacation in Brazil) were even questioned about these events. The criminal proceedings for the floods in La Plata were closed with a single accused, Sergio Ariel Lezana, a Civil Defense official of that city, who accepted his guilt and requested the maximum penalty for the crime of "breach of public official duties." Thus, the penalty was established as a payment of $12,500 and a one-year disqualification from holding public office. Lezana was the first official to be subjected to an oral and public trial for the flood and was to be tried jointly with the provincial Civil Defense chief, Miguel Ángel Di Lorenzo, but the latter passed away months before the trial.

The National University of La Plata, together with the National Technological University, proposed an Integrated Disaster Risk Management Plan (GRID) and created the Water Emergency collection within the Intellectual Creation Dissemination Service, the institutional repository of UNLP, to gather works (articles, technical reports, books, and others) that contribute to the development of the plan and serve as a database for future work in the area.

On April 8, 2013, the national government, through the National Social Security Administration (ANSES), detailed measures to assist those affected by the floods, including low-interest credit lines and subsidies for retirees and pensioners, beneficiaries of the Universal Child Allowance (AUH) and Pregnancy Allowance (AUE), Family Allowances, and Unemployment Insurance, thus covering the most vulnerable affected individuals. Those who received the minimum retirement or a contributory pension, beneficiaries of the Universal Child Allowance, Family Salary, and the Progresar Plan were benefited. Residents requested subsidies for all those affected, and the national government offered them loans to be repaid with low-interest rates, as well as subsidies for retirees and pregnant women. They also requested the cessation of municipal and national tax and fee collections. These benefits would be available to those affected by the floods in the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires, La Plata, La Matanza, San Martín, Berisso, and Ensenada. According to the Budget, the Secretariat of Social Development will allocate $30,000,000 in subsidies for residents of La Plata who suffered from the flooding, as reported to Diagonales by official councilors.

According to the Diario Clarín, the losses from the floods in La Plata amounted to $2.618 billion. One in four properties was directly affected by the storm, and each affected family would need an average of $78,000 to repair their home and replace the goods they lost. According to a preliminary report conducted in the municipality of La Plata, 58,582 properties were affected by the rains. Of the total affected properties, 55,716 correspond to homes, while 2,846 are businesses and garages. It is estimated that 25% of La Plata residents were directly affected by the catastrophe, while the figure exceeds 55% of the party's population if those who lost a car or suffered other types of damages are considered. After the flood, a hydraulic works plan was launched to double the drainage system of the entire Buenos Aires capital region (La Plata, Berisso, and Ensenada). The plan is implemented through the Directorate of Hydraulic Works, which will require an investment of about $2 billion by the province—largely financed by the national government—and will be carried out in parallel stages, with one of the main objectives being to widen the channel of the El Gato stream, which receives 70% of the water that drains in the capital region—carrying all the water from the urban area as well as that from the Regimiento and Pérez streams—and discharges it into the Río de la Plata.

The president decided on military intervention. By order of the Ministry of Defense, the Argentine Army initiated a deployment that would total 1,200 personnel. The I Armored Brigade activated a crisis committee, where the 7th Mechanized Infantry Regiment, the 1st Armored Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron, and the 8th Tank Cavalry Regiment began evacuation and transportation tasks. In the center of La Plata, a mobile water treatment plant with a capacity of 2,000 liters of water per hour was installed, supported by a sachet-packing machine. The 601st Engineer Battalion, the 601st Air Assault Regiment, the Buenos Aires Military Garrison Command, the National Military College, the Army Non-Commissioned Officers School "Sargento Cabral," the 1st Infantry Regiment, and the 601st Military Police Company were added to the tasks, which also came to include the loading, transportation, and delivery of supplies in more than 80 mobilized trucks. The overflow in logistics centers due to the large number of donations caused the 601st Communications Group to begin operating as a receiver of items contributed by society, to which the 7th Mechanized Infantry Regiment had to add its facilities days later. The National Military College provided 60 health cadets to the health centers involved in the assistance tasks. From Olavarría, the 1st Armored Engineer Squadron deployed sappers for debris removal tasks, which, with the collaboration of other units, managed to collect tens of thousands of tons. The teleinformatic and integrated support of the Army with the different Security Forces and institutions such as Civil Defense, Caritas, and the Red Cross was handled by personnel and equipment from the 601st Communications Company, the 602nd Communications Battalion, and the 1st Armored Communications Squadron. These units provided satellite telephony, videoconferencing, image transmission, and Internet, and were supported cartographically by the 1st Armored Intelligence Squadron.

Different sectors of Argentine society mobilized to gather donations for the benefit of those affected. All kinds of goods were collected and sent, including cleaning supplies, food, mattresses, blankets, and even appliances, coming from all parts of the country and distributed in the affected areas. Due to the volume of donations, organizing the shipments became complicated. Thousands of young people from across the country mobilized to the affected areas to volunteer in the restoration of neighborhoods that had been destroyed by the floods. Pope Francis donated US$50,000 to help the flood victims. Although most of the volunteers were self-organized young people, parishes and scout groups also participated, as well as young activists from political and social organizations.
